Colins erythromelon. By Frank Finn, B.A., F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. 1 he Mouse-birds or Colies ( Coliidac ) are a very peculiar and isolated family of birds; the species are few, all much alike in form and size--about that of a Sparrow, except for the long tail--and confined to Africa south of the Sahara. They are very arboreal in their habits; in the small experience I had of them in Hast Africa, I never saw one on the ground, nor have [ ever heard of their going there when wild. Their feet are very peculiar, the first and fourth toes turning either forward cr backward, so as to give a firm yet changeable grip; yet their eg-joints seem very weak, for they straddle a great deal, and ;quat down on their stomachs like a bird whose feet are sore. They generally sleep hanging up in a bunch, but not head lown like the Hanging-parrakeets or Bat-parrots ( Loriculus ), the lead being up at the level of the toes--feet upwards, but not lead downwards, in fact. One would expect them to nest in ioles, as they are rather parrakeet-like in some ways, but they eally build open nests of twigs in a bush or tree. They are easy subjects for aviculture, and of particular interest, because, in pite of their ugly crawling movements and their dirtiness, hey are worth breeding from a scientific point of view, as hardly nything seems to be known about their young, except that these re of the helpless type, and have down of the very scantiest haracter, so that they are practically naked. In all Mouse-birds, nfortunately, the sexes are alike, so that it is hard to select airs. Their food consists chiefly of fruit and buds, with a few usects ; so that they are easily suited with artificial food.

The Red-faced Mouse-bird. Two species, both South African, are in the market at present, the Striated Mouse-bird (Colins striatus ), and the Red- cheeked (C. erythromeloji) figured in our illustration ; from this the Striated may be easily distinguished by having the bill black and grey and the eye-cere black, while the feet are dull dark red instead of bright coral, and the plumage is dull drab with fine pencilling. For the following interesting notes on the much prettier Red-faced species, I am indebted to our member Major B. R. Horsbrugh :-- " I bad many of this species brought in to me by trappers at both Potchefstroom (Transvaal) and Bloemfontein (O. R. C.) but I found them dirty, greedy, and expensive to keep, so that one day I released all I had except a pair that I brought home in 1906 and presented to the Zoo. They are perfectly easy to keep, any fruit does them for diet, and they are not in the least quarrelsome with other species. They have a very swift flight indeed, and look very pheasant-like as they shoot along with their long thin pointed tails carried stiffly behind them. The tail-feathers are very hard and wiry indeed, and I do not think it has been observed before that their skins are quite extraordinarily thick and tough, so that they can hardly be torn by the hands in a fresh- killed bird. They are interesting birds in some ways and I can con- fidently recommend them as inmates of a mixed aviary in this country; but they will not stand cold at all, and die at once if subjected to severe weather." This species has been observed to line its nest with wild cotton in seed, while the Striated uses green leaves; the latter seems to lay pure white eggs, those of the Red-cheeked being mottled and streaked with red. Besides the above two species, the following have been exhibited at the London Zoological Gardens :-- White-backed Mouse-bird {Colins capensis ); distinguished by a white black-edged patch on the back, followed by a maroon one; South African. This species nested in 1892 in one of the large waggon-shaped flight cages in which these birds

Our Society a?id its Work. were then kept in the London Zoo Parrot-liouse, two of them sitting on several eggs in the same nest, as stated in the Ibis for that year. Chestnut-backed Mouse-bird (C. castanonotus)\ also with a maroon patch on the back, but no white above it; West African. Beack-necked Mouse-bird (C. nigricollis') ; also West African ; very like the Striated, but with black forehead and chin. OUR SOCIETY AND ITS WORK. By Dr. A. G. Butter. Our Editor has asked me, as one of the original members |of the Avicultural Society, to sketch our history and the work done by our body since its inception : and although I feel sure that others of our members would be far better able to do justice to this subject than myself, I cannot be so churlish as to refuse to do my best to enlighten certain outsiders who are seeking for information. It was in the summer or autumn of 1894 that Messrs. H. R. Fillmer and C. S. Simpson of Brighton communicated with Mr. Reginald Phillipps and myself with a view to founding a Society for the study of British and Foreign Birds, both in freedom and captivity. These gentlemen visited me at the Natural History Museum at South Kensington and briefly dis- cussed the objects of the Society, the means by which those objects should be attained, and lastly the title by which it should be known. It was decided that, in order to encourage and assist one mother in bird-study the members must have some means of ntercommunication, in addition to that afforded by the post; ind, as it would be impossible for us to hold general meetings, t was agreed that a Journal should be published in monthly Darts to which the members should be invited to contribute ; bus not only recording their own successes and failures, their hews on housing and feeding, with other matters of mutual nterest, but at the same time bequeathing the results of their [study for the benefit of their successors.

Dr. A. G. Butler, As regards the title, the term " Fancy'* was at once rejected as objectionable, and as applicable chiefly to those variations from species produced by the agency of man; "Ornithology" was decided to be too general a term ; I therefore suggested that, as we proposed to deal with birds much as gardeners did with flowers, and as the latter study was known as "Floriculture" and " Horticulture," we might surely use the term "Aviculture " : this term was eventually agreed upon, and our body issued its first modest volume of 132 pages 011 November 1st, 1894. Unfortunately the list of members which appeared in Volume I. of the Avicultural Magazine included only fifty-two individuals, and as at that time the entrance fee was but lialf-a- crown and the subscription five shillings, it was not surprising that it was impossible to afford illustrations either for this or the second volume; although, by the end of 1895, the member- ship had increased to 175, among the accessions to our body being some of our most successful breeders. With over two hundred members at the end of 1896, it was possible to afford four coloured plates by scientific artists, as well as one or two cuts to illustrate Volume III. ; and, from that time, not only was the success of the Society assured, but there was a marked improvement in the character of the work done by the members: by the end of 1897 the membership numbered two hundred and sixty-one, a very strong argument in favour of the attractiveness of good coloured illustrations! With the completion of Volume V. the annual subscription became 7/6 ; the entrance fee however still remained 2/6. At that time there was no increase in the number of plates, the member- ship not having varied greatly since 1897. The magazine continued gradually to increase in size and importance ; so that Volume VIII. the last of the first series, contained no less than 318 pages of text with seventeen illustra- tions, including seven coloured plates ; and the expansion was most strongly marked in this volume, which inaugurated the very successful editorship of Mr. D. Seth-Smith: during the entire reign of this energetic ruler the Magazine greatly prospered, as indeed we have every reason to believe it will do in the hands of his successor.

on our Society and its Work. Of the very valuable work done by our Society there can )e no question. Not only have numerous species been bred for he first time by many of our members and thereby a knowledge )f the life-history of the species has been completed, but iri several cases disputed points have been satisfactorily cleared up. vTrs. Johnstone's successes in breeding Fraser's Touracou have hrown considerable light on the relationship of the Touracous o the Hoatzin and to the Cuckoos, and Mr. Seth-Smith's studies n breeding Hemipodes and Tinamous have established the Dolyandrous character of these birds, a fact already indicated >ut not cleared up in the case of certain species by Lieut. Hautli n Germany. The zeal of some of our wealthy members has been the Means of bringing to light new and interesting species of birds diicli might otherwise have remained unappreciated for many ears to come, and even an insignificant member like myself las been permitted to clear up a few points of synonymy, as in he cases of Q:ielea russi, Paroaria cervicalis and Petronia albigu- iris, the first two being mere plumages, but the third at least a istinct race. The anatomical articles by Mr. Pycraft and those by Prof. . O. Whitman and others of our American friends are all of Dnsiderable scientific importance. Lastly, in many cases where young have not been reared 1 captivity, it has been possible to secure young plumages, erectly describe the eggs for the first time, and to deposit becimens in the National Collection for the benefit of cabinet- orkers. Then, apart from the good work which we know to have sen done, there are the ideas and suggestions which occur from me to time to the student of living birds ; many of them per- aps very ridiculous, but some of them perchance capable of ading up to truth, and therefore worth recording : it does not lswer to despise the day of small things or the feeble glimmer- gs of light emitted from small minds, for behold how great a atter a little fire kindleth! The creation of our Society has produced a need for works ialing with aviculture, and thus has kept some of us pretty

Mr. D. Seth-Smith, busy; and the wish to give of our best to the public, has doubt- less stimulated us to close and careful study, with the result that both we and our readers have benefited by increased knowledge of our subject. Most of the coloured illustrations in the Avicultural Maga- zine have been carefully copied from living birds, and thus the natural actions of the different species and the correct outlines of their bodies have been faithfully reproduced : this is often quite impossible in the case of illustrations drawn from dried skins, some of which are mere caricatures. Although for some years past the annual subscription to our Society has been ten shillings and the entrance fee half-a- guinea, the value of the Magazine has so greatly increased both as regards bulk, interest and the number of its illustrations that the increase of its membership to close upon 450 is by no means surprising; the only marvel is that more bird-lovers do not join our ranks.
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON MY VISIT TO AUSTRALIA.
algorithms.bodyText: By David Seth-Smith, F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. (<Continued from page J54.) BRISBANE. Although the time of my departure was drawing near, I was most anxious if possible to make an expedition to Brisbane, as I was well aware that some of the best and rarest of the fauna which I hoped to obtain, had its home in Queensland. I had moreover been in correspondence with a live-stock dealer named Beard in Brisbane from whose letters I judged that a visit to that town might result in some very valuable additions to my collect- tion of living creatures. The easiest way to travel to Brisbane, providing the weather is calm, is by steamer, but the weather has a way of being very rough round the Australian coast just at the time when one has decided to travel, and the coastal boats, although excellent in many ways, are somewhat noted for their capacity for rolling. The N.S.W. Government having, moreover, generously granted me a pass 011 their railways, I decided without hesitation to travel by train.
algorithms.figure: 07 i his Visit to Australia.
algorithms.bodyText: The train journey occupies about thirty hours, the distance )eing nearly 600 miles. I left Sydney at 5.10 p.m. on February :9th, arriving in Brisbane about n p.m. the following evening. Some of the scenery is most beautiful, especially the first part as me approaches the Hawkesbury River and obtains numerous glimpses of large expanses of water surrounded by forest and lotted with islets. Much of the country consists of rocky ground, thickly covered with bush, which is absolutely useless or cultivation, but ideal as a sanctuary fordhe native fauna. The greyish foliage of the Eucalyptus is now and then elieved by a patch of feathery whiteness--a gum-tree in full lower. The same trees do not bloom every year, but every year ome trees are in bloom, and apparently at almost all times of he year, and these flowering trees provide an abundant supply >f food for the honey-eating birds of which Australia possesses o many species. This inaccessible country also unfortunately >rovides ample shelter for the introduced fox, which is becoming curse by its ravages not only amongst the native mammals and ground birds--the Lyre-bird and Mallee-bird in particular--but mongst the flock-owners' lambs. At Newcastle, the colliery town of New South Wales, we lad to turn out of the train and snatch a hurried dinner, for the Government has not yet seen the advantage of providing dining ccommodation 011 its trains. We reached Wallangarra on the )tieensland Border the following morning, and here passengers lust change, as the gauge of the Queensland railways is narrower lian that of the older state, which has adopted the standard English gauge of rail. O11 the Queensland side the railway crosses the Darling )owns, winding in and out among the hills, and much of the cenery is very beautiful. I saw several Wallabies as they hopped away at the side of ae line, and on one occasion a splendid pair of Australian lustards or "Wild Turkeys" rose from the plain and flew for erhaps half a mile, alighting in a field still within view of the rain. We passed through country which is badly infested by the rickly pear, this plant nearly covering the ground in places

Mr. D. Seth-Smith, and spoiling the pasture land. The Emu, I am told, is accused of distributing the seed of this plant, and in consequence these fine birds are being killed off in many districts. Arriving in Brisbane late at night, I put up at an Hotel close to the Botanical Gardens, and through my open window heard the weird squeakings of the numerous Fruit-bats or "Flying Foxes" which fed on the fruit of the Moreton Bay fig trees, of which many fine specimens were growing within a stone's throw. The noise of hundreds of frogs in these gardens, which every night set up a regular concert, will also remain long in my memory. Mr. Beard, the animal dealer, had promised to procure me what he could, and I took an early opportunity of calling upon him. In his shop, however, I saw nothing but domestic pigeons and rabbits, which was not encouraging. He assured me, how- ever, that he could procure me some very good animals, and that he already had some of the beautiful Parry's, or, as they are locally called "Pretty-faced" Wallabies, and some Brush Tur- keys for me. He told me that he knew of a pair of the Beautiful Parrakeet (.Psephoius piilcherrimus) in captivity which he hoped to be able to secure. This species appears to be very local, and he knew of a place where a pair regularly bred each year. It is locally known as the " Elegant Parrakeet." A story he related to me of the Squatter Pigeon ( Geophaps, scripta) presents an aspect of the character of some of the Australian so-called sportsmen which is anything but sportsman- like. Three years before my visit these Ground Doves had been very numerous in the neighbourhood, and he received no less than 400 of them from the catchers. He offered them to the Sydney dealers, who declined them ; but a party of pigeon shooters bought the entire lot, all of which they used in shooting matches ! When one remembers how rarely this, the handsome Partridge Bronzewing, is seen in this country, and how glad private aviculturists and European Zoological Gardens would be to obtain specimens, one can only be horrified at this wanton destruction. The Brisbane Botanical Gardens are very well laid out
on his Visit to Australia.

with many kinds of beautiful tropical and semi-tropical vege- tation such as Palms of all kinds and masses of giant Bamboo. The beautiful scarlet Hibiscus was in full flower, and, I watched with much delight a lovely blood-red Honey-eater (Myzomela sanguinolenta) sucking at the flowers and flying from one to another, almost putting the brilliant flowers themselves in the shade by his brilliance. There was a small collection of animals in these gardens, but nothing of special interest except perhaps a Banksian Cockatoo, which I, with some difficulty, persuaded the authorities to let me take home. Emus, and a nice collection of Wallabies, always attracted the public, and it struck me what a splendid Zoological Garden could be run in so ideal a climate, and in a country containing so many interesting forms of animal life. As I was looking at these creatures one afternoon, I heard overhead the cries of Lorikeets, and looking up saw two large locks of Swainson's Lorikeets, orobablv each containing some Ifty birds or so, flying very rapidly, the bright sunshine showing 1 blaze of colour on their brilliant undersides. So common are hese birds in the neighbourhood, that I was able to buy a cage nil, containing fifty birds, for the sum of thirty shillings. I anded thirty-one of these birds safely and they made a fine .how during the summer in the London Zoo. The Sacred Kingfisher was always to be found at the side >f a pond surrounded with bamboos, a spot which also was the eeding ground of several of the elegant Pied Grallinas. Brisbane has a very fair museum, where I saw a collection i"f Queensland animals that was extremely good numerically, >ut the labelling was by 110 means faultless and many of the ases were very badly arranged. Brisbane hopes also to have a Zoo. one day ; at least a few nthusiasts are trying their best to get one. I saw the proposed ite, which was good, and I only hope they may have their Zoo. nd teach the people of Brisbane something of the animals their ountrv contains, of which the average settler is woefully gnorant. ( To be conthiued.J
algorithms.reference: Mr. W. E. Teschemaker,
algorithms.sectionHeader: NESTING OF THE RED-WHISKERED BULBUL ( Oloco?npsa jocosa ).
algorithms.bodyText: By W. E. Teschemaker, B.A. I have found this quite an interesting species and have noted several points in connection with its nesting habits and sexual distinctions which would be worth discussing if space permitted, but the last two accounts I contributed to our Maga- zine were so long that I must on this occasion be more brief. Although I have had various individual Bulbuls at one time or another I never tried my hand at breeding them until last summer. Nearly all the Bulbuls are dangerous in a mixed community, but O. jocosa appears to be a somewhat notable ex- ception. It is distinctly a sociable bird, and I think might be safely trusted in any aviary. One of mine struck up a close friendship with a Magpie Tanager, and did not seem the least afraid of the latter's formidable hooked beak and hawk-like yellow eye. Several pairs will nest in close proximity in the same aviary and, as we shall see in the course of this narrative, two hens will even share a nest. Bulbuls seem to offer a promising field to the would-be- medallist, because, although there are more than fifty species of this family in India alone (if we include local races), I believe only one species besides O* jocosa has fully reared young in this country, namely, P. haemorrhous. Yet they seem generally anxious to breed, and at least three species (the Syrian, Philip- pine and White-eared) have incubated. The subject of our present notice ranges from the Hima- layas to Assam and throughout Burma and S. China, and has at least two local races : (i.) O. enteria, from Bengal. (ii.) O.fuscicaudata , from Southern India. The former of these is the most frequently imported, and is distinguished by the white tips of its tail-feathers and by the dark necklace being broken in the centre. There was a large importation of this species in 1909, which were retailed by the trade at the not extravagant figure of three shillings and six- pence each. The first thing that struck one on looking through this consignment was that they ran in two distinct sizes. I
on Nesting of the Red-whiske?ed Bnlbnl.

elected two of each size and will not go further into the matter hail to say that I fancy that the two large birds were a pair nd the two small birds were two hens. First nest. Although all birds try to hide their nesting perations from us, they are as a rule singularly unsuccessful,, ecause the aviarist can generally tell by a mere glance whether bird is going to lay, has laid, is incubating, or has hatched. Tow and again I go through the aviaries with a good big stick a case any bird should be " playing possum." I bush-whacked lie Bulbuls' aviary (which by the way was only 17ft. by 10ft.) arly in June and only succeeded in beating out two Bulbuls : a unt for corpses produced no results, and therefore I could only onclude that the other two Bulbuls were actually sitting. I xamined the shrubs carefully, but they contained no nests. I len gave each shrub a thorough shaking--and the mystery was olved. A dead branch of a Cupressus was leaning against the r ire netting, and between the two and not attached in any way ) either was the nest, containing six eggs and with the two lissing Bulbuls sitting side by side. Capt. Perreau tells me that our friend Whiskers is regarded 1 his own country as a bit of a fool : he falls unsuspectingly into le most elementary trap and builds his nest in the most con- ficuous and ill-chosen places. It is evident to me however that, though Whiskers may not be born wise, he acquires wisdom ith great facility. I never saw a better hidden nest than this, id what especially impressed me was that its constructors must ave realized that their only chance of success was to conceal from the malevolent eyes of the pair of White-crested Jay brushes in the same aviary, because the third, fourth and fifth -Sts were built in ordinary situations. Perhaps someone may ;k how can any stupid species be abundant in a land of hawks, lakes, crows, cats, mongooses and fowlers. I expect our friend r hiskers succeeds by perseverance. If he loses a nest he does ot sit in sackcloth and ashes : he sets to work at once and arts another. It must be understood that Capt. Perreau is res- msible for the above estimate of the intelligence of Whiskers: ^rsonally I have found him most wary, secretive and suspicious. 1 1904, and again in 1905, I had communal nests of the Indian

Mr. W. E. Teschemaker, Avadavat, the two liens incubating and feeding the young jointly and in perfect amity, and the young were fully reared, but this nest was not so fortunate : in a few days' time the eggs were thrown out and broken. They were all fertile and had been incubated apparently about a week. Second nest. I now removed the Jay Thrushes and Pekin Robins and left the four Bulbuls in undisturbed possession of the aviary. I do not seem to have made any notes about the second nest, and all I can remember about it is that the eggs were laid in the same nest and again thrown out after a few days' incu- bation. The eggs are smaller than one would expect, and are closely covered with small red and purplish spots, closely re- sembling one type of egg of the House-sparrow and of much the same size (90 mm x 62 111m). The usual clutch appears to be three. Third nest. Another nest was now commenced in the very top of another shrub about five feet from the ground. These Bulbuls are said to buiid small neat nests, but tliose-I have seen have been very loosely compacted of hay and unlined, probably owing to want of suitable materials. Once more three eggs were laid and incubation commenced on the 14th July. As it was evident that the two (or more) hens were jealous, I tried, hard to ascertain which birds had constructed this nest--but in vain. They were so extraordinarily secretive that I could never get a glimpse of them whilst pairing or building. I therefore deter- mined to remove all but the one actually incubating, and even this proved a very difficult matter because she (or he) would always slip away into the thickest covert, when put off the nest, and thus elude identification. However, I at last ascertained that it was the largest Bulbul which was sitting, and I at once removed the other three. Two young were hatched on the 23rd, after the unusually short period of nine days' incubation. The young were quite naked and grew with astonishing rapiditj'. On the 25th, after a night of continuous rain, the nest collapsed, but I fixed it up again and lashed it firmly in place, for which assistance Whiskers seemed very grateful. O11 the 27th, the wind piped up to a gale from the S.W., and it rained in torrents for twelve consecutive hours. This unlucky day cost me two medals. I

on Nesting of the Red-whiskered Bulbul. svas away from home for a few days, so poor Whiskers had no assistance whatever in sheltering and feeding the young and, as vas only to be expected, they succumbed. Fourth nest. I felt quite sure from what I had seen of he perseverance of the Whiskers family that they would have *mother try, so I drafted back two of the three I had recently emoved. Not having any idea as to which were males and vhicli females I selected the other large bird and one small one. ly the iotli August the Bulbuls were incubating another clutch *f three eggs, which hatched on the 19th ; but a day of continuous ain on the 20th was too much for the young birds. Fifth nest. These untoward events seemed to indicate hat the young required warmth and some shelter from the rain, o I fixed up a basket-nest and a rain screen, the advantages of /hicli the Bulbuls were not slow to recognise, for they soon had wo more young in hand, and these, when I left home on the 2nd Sept., were growing apace. I returned on the 5th October, nd was told there had been an epidemic of some sort amongst lie fruit-eating birds, and that all the Bulbuls except one were ead. I was, therefore, not a little astonished to discover two vely little Bulbuls sitting side by side in the middle of a clump f privet. Although they were tiny little things they had well eveloped crests, white cheeks, and, in fact, resembled the adults 1 every respect, except that the under tail-coverts were paler nd the necklace only faintly indicated. By the 18th Oct. the ecklace was quite distinct. O11 the iotli Nov. I caught up the oung Bulbuls and brought them into the house, and I then noted lat, whereas in the adults the four outer rectrices 011 each side e tipped with white, in the young only the outer rectrix was ) marked. I was glad to find a good home for the youngsters id their sole surviving parent with one of our members. It is iteresting to note that the surviving parent was the second rgest bird, and therefore, if it was a female, as one would infer 0111 its size, the other large bird, which incubated the third utcli of eggs and took sole charge of the young, must have ien a male. However, as I said before, I am not at all sure hat the sexes of any of the four Bulbuls really were. When I look back upon the many vicissitudes which these

Mr. T. H. Newman, young Bulbuls underwent, the terrible weather of last September and October, the gales of wind, the long cold nights, and the many days when I .$aw them huddled together in a soaking downpour of rain, when I reflect that they were reared by a single parent, and that that parent only escaped death from contagious disease by a fluke, I can only repeat the remark of the Duke of Wellington anent a certain great and historic battle --"it was a deuced close run thing."

By T. H. Newman, F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. I think we all like to read about wild birds, and in fact it seems to me almost the duty of anyone who keeps birds, to try and find out what has been written about their natural habits, what sort of country they inhabit, what is the lowest temperature they are subjected to, and so forth. I am sure many of our members must from time to time come across interesting birds during their travels, but a glance down the " Contents" columns of the volumes of our Magazine, does not show that many have given us their experiences; this must, therefore, be my excuse for jotting down these few notes about the birds I met with during a recent five weeks' tour to Tunis and through Algeria, although they only deal with the commonest species. As I did not decide to go until it was nearly time for starting, I had not much opportunity beforehand to read up about what sort of birds I was likely to come across. Many very interesting papers dealing with the ornithology of this region appeared in the earliest volumes of The Ibis , and latterly Mr. Whitaker has contributed a series of articles which have cul- minated in his two beautiful volumes on "The Birds of Tunisia." I was greatly indebted to this work when compiling these notes, and have generally followed the nomenclature there used ; as unfortunately I found these books too heavy to take with me, my modus operandi was to tick off all the species, as far as possible, mentioned by Mr. Whitaker, in Mr. Dresser's " Manual of Palse- arctic Birds." I also made a list of the species of especial in terest; in this way, when a bird was clearly seen, it was nearly always

Notes from North- West Africa. 2 r - o >ossible at least to determine the family to which it belonged, nd a glance down the species marked in the Manual generally es ulted in the exact identification. I cannot imagine anyone ailing to be greatly edified by a visit to this part of the world, vhich presents so many varied objects of interest; but no one vll * does llot care ^ the feathered inhabitants of a country can ealise what a vastly added delight there is in coming across *irds which aie either quite unknown or rare with us, and of bserving them under conditions very different from those at ome. Our party was a small one, consisting only of three others esides myself, which often gave me opportunities for lookin*. nt for birds which I should not have had had we been a larger timber. We started on 12th of November last. On the way down ) Dover I noticed a few Lapwings ( Vanellus vane/lus) and Black- eaded Gulls (Lams ridibundus) in the fields. We had a good tossing to Calais, though it was rather cold and inclined to min ; flock of Gulls followed the boat, among which were recognised tie Lesser Black-backed (L. fuscus ) and a few Black-headed ; lere were some also which looked like Common Gulls (L. cairns), s we neaied Calais, four Gannets (Sula bassana ) were seen ; )ine were flying just over the surface of the water, while others ere at a considerable height. Gulls also became more numerous, gain apparently mostly Common, though there seemed to be *me young Herring-Gulls (Lams argentatus ) among them. Ihe 13th was spent in Paris; we were quite glad to leave behind in the evening after a damp and very muddy day. We leached Marseilles early next morning in brilliant nsliine. After lunch I took the opportunity to visit the Zoo; is small, though prettily laid out in the upper part of the City, * hind the Palais de Longecamp; beautiful trees and shrubs liming by 110 means the least attractive feature. It is under the mie management as the Jardin d'Acclimatation at Paris, and rves as a resting-place for animals destined either for Paris for exportation. There were not very many birds; the first be seen were two Flamingoes (.Phocnicopterns roseus ) in a it of giotto; some Canada Geese were in a pond with a fine

Mr. T. H. Newman, waterfall at the back. Under the arches of a viaduct which rum across the gardens, were a fine pair of Condors and some very perfect Bearded and Griffon Vultures. In another part of the gardens were four Ostriches, one being a cock, a couple of Rheas, and two young Emus. A range of aviaries contained a few oi the commoner species of Pheasants and some common Peafowls, some being white ; a quantity of domestic Pigeons and Poultry are also kept; among the latter were several cocks of the curious naked-necked variety. In another row of small aviaries were a nice Hobby ( Falco subbuleo ) and some Kestrels ( Tinnunculm tinnunculus ), apparently newly arrived, as they were very wild and kept flying against the bars and uttering screams; there were also some Barn and Eagle Owls. Some Magpies shared one com- partment with a Jackdaw, said to have been obtained in France, which showed very pale grey, almost white on the sides of the neck. Two Macaws, together with some of the commoner Cockatoos, a Lesser Vasa Parrot, also a Blue-fronted Amazon, were on perches hung under some trees; elsewhere I came across a Crowned Crane (Bolearzcapavonina), a couple of Wood- Ibises (probably African) a Great White Egret and some Purple Gallinules. In a grassy enclosure were some Gulls of several species, some fine White Storks, a female Australian Sheld-duck, an Egyptian Goose, a pair of Black Swans, and what I took to be a Shag; it had a distinct crest at the back of its head, which I should hardly have expected at this date. Yet another range oi four or five enclosures contained a number ot Barbary Doves, a Common Turtle-dove and a hybrid Turtle x Barbary; a quantity of Java Sparrows, some Weavers, and a few other small birds occupied another of the compartments. I noticed an Emerald- spotted Dove--or had it purple spots?--a number of Barred Doves, and, most interesting of all, a Dove which I believe to have been an Aldabran Turtle-dove (Turtur aldabranus) from its resemblance to the Madagascar Turtle ( 7 '. picturatus )--(see Avic. Mag ., Vol. VI., N.S., p. 79)--being of the same purple vinous tint as that species, but having the head also of this colour instead of grey, it seemed also a little smaller ; it was very like the plate in P.Z.S. 1871. A Half-collared Turtle-dove was bully- ing it. The most noteworthy Mammal seemed to be a white

iind, probably a Red Deer ; she had I believe pink eyes, there vas a curious brown patch on one flank, and a yellowish tinge urrounded the tail. Rater in the afternoon we visited the rocky slet of the Chateau d'lf. I saw some Gulls flying near the Island but did not identify the species. O11 the ]5th, we embarked at midday for Tunis; a large lock of Yellow-legged Herring-Gulls (Laws cachumans'), mostly dult birds--but some young ones in the mottled grey plumage oubtless belonged to the same species--also a few Black-headed hills, followed 11s. I watched them from the stern of the boat 3r some time ; the Yellow-legged form of Herring-Gull differs Iso from our bird by having a darker grey mantle : the bright ellow bills and feet of the adult birds were very conspicuous, ix or seven continued to follow until darkness came on. Owing to the rough and wet weather I did not come on eck until late next morning, which was a matter for regret, as arlier in the day we had passed along near the Western coast of ardinia, and as this is one of the chief breeding places of the ire and beautiful Audouin's Gull (L. aiidoumi ) it was here if tiywhere that I had hoped to see it ; but, although I kept a good >ok out for a pale grey Gull with a coral-red bill with a black and, I never saw one. About a dozen Yellow-legged Herring nils were in sight: they kept close behind the ship. During le early part of the afternoon the African coast was sighted; a mg line of irregular hills ending in the low promontory of Cape artliage, which we rounded soon after dark, and steamed slowly ong the canal through the El-Bahira Rake, getting some pretty fects in the water from the reflected lights which dotted the hole shore 011 our right, while a crescent moon, partly hid by ouds, hung low down just ahead, above which Venus blazed ightly. We landed at Tunis just before eight o'clock. It can be imagined with what eagerness next morning, most before it was light, I seated myself by the window and oked out to see what birds were stirring. A few nondescript wls were visible in a neighbouring yard, flocks of domestic Igeons were also seen circling round ; presently a large Gull speared, which was later on followed by a whole flock flying Igh overhead. Some Sparrows were observed perching 011 some

Mr. T. H. Newman, telegraph wires; when one flew nearer it seemed to have a chestnut-coloured crown, so I took it to be a Spanish Sparrow (Passer hispa?iiole?isis'), as I knew Mr. Whitaker had stated that this was the common Sparrow of Tunisia. Here I will pause to make a few remarks about the Sparrows I met with ; they were *certainly the most generally distributed birds I saw, being met with everywhere ; numerically I must have seen more Sparrows, with the possible exception of Crested Larks, than any other birds. I devoted a considerable time to watching them, and confess myself much puzzled ; they were as a rule not nearly so tame as ours at home, and objected to being watched. Certainly at least two types of Sparrows were common ; there were those with dis- tinct chestnut crowns, which were always seen in or near towns, and which, knowing Mr. Whitaker's opinion, and that most surely he should know, I always gaily put down as Spanish Sparrows; but on looking up figures of the Italian and Spanish Sparrows in Dresser's "Birds of Europe," I find that while many of the birds I saw very closely resembled the former, I certainly never noticed a bird with so much black on the breast and flanks as depicted for the latter. When Canon Tristram wrote in The Ibis for 185c \0x25A0" On the Ornithology of Northern Africa," he was of opinion that the form which was found in the towns, with habits resem- bling our own bird, was the Italian Sparrow ( P . italics), while the Spanish Sparrow, though very abundant, especially in the salt marshes, and always breeding near water, avoided in Africa as a rule, the habitations of men, and in habits differed greatl} from the House Sparrow (P. domesticus). O11 the other hand, Mr Whitaker has no hesitation in saying that the Spanish Sparrow is the common species both in towns and in the open country and is doubtful if the Italian species occurs in Tunis, in wliicl supposition he is doubtless correct. It seems that both these chestnut-crowned forms vary considerably in different localities and that the Italian form sometimes approaches the Hous^ Sparrow in all but the colour of the crown ; all these form* appear to breed together indiscriminately wherever they happei to meet. Then there was a Sparrow which I often saw awaj from the towns, generally when there were only a few building. 4 near ; it was a neat, greyer looking-bird, with 110 chestnut on the

Notes from Noith- West Africa. :rown and only a small black patch on the throat; I used to put liese down as Tree Sparrows (P. montanus ), but Mr. Whitaker *ays this species is not common in Tunisia, and that it is rather are in Algeria. The morning was spent exploring the higher part of the own. Tunis is too well known, neither is this the place, for a iescription ; it is sufficient to say that the modern French town ;xtends from the harbour along the shores of the lagoon of il-Bahira, the so-called Take of Tunis, occupying the flat neigh- bouring land, behind which is situated the ancient native quarter >n somewhat higher ground. I saw two bird-shops, which, how- ever, had nothing of more interest to show than a few Canaries md a very tame Blue-fronted Amazon Parrot. The streets are r eiy narrow, mostly paved with rough stones ; many were covered >ver with arched roofs like arcades ; the native Bazaars or Souks re even more Oriental and picturesque than those of Cairo or Constantinople. The shops are small square places open in rout; the proprietor squats on one side surrounded by his 7 oods. In the afternoon we visited the Palace known as the Bardo, idiicli is about two miles outside the town ; it is surrounded by ;ardens containing many beautiful flowering shrubs and trees, moug which a large flock of Sparrows were making a great noise ike their relatives at home before going to roost; they were ather shy and so hidden among the leaves that I could not get a ,ood view of them, but two I saw on the building seemed to have hestnut-coloured crowns, so very likely they were all Spanish Sparrows. The 18th was a bright morning after heavy rain, which jiade the streets very muddy. In the morning I came across notlier bird-shop with a quantity of Canaries ; one cage con- lined several Serin Finches ( Serinus serums) and a hen North kfrican Greenfinch (. Ligurians chlo?is aura? it liven t? is ) which I 7 as veiy pleased to see, as it was one of the birds I was anxious ) meet with ; I shall have something more to say of these birds iter on, as I afterwards came across both species at large. A Goldfinch ( Carduelis carduelis ) occupied another cage. There 'as also a Blackbird : I was not able to notice any difference in

Mr. T. H. Newman, the Blackbirds I saw from those witli ns, but the resident form has a larger and stouter bill, and the hens are greyer than our bird. I heard Blackbirds several times, but they were always very wild, and I was never able to get more than a glance at the ] birds as they dived into cover ; the North African form is known i as the Moorish Blackbird (Turdus menila viauritanica). Later i on I saw another Goldfinch, this time a young bird, in a small cage hanging outside a shop. In the afternoon we took the Galetto motor train for Carthage; the line runs along a raised embankment right across the El-Bahira Lagoon, alongside of which the canal has been constructed which now joins Tunis to Galetto, and so connects it with the open sea. Small birds were fairly numerous along the line, and I also saw a small flock of Waders, which flew alongside the train over the water; they were probably Dunlins (Tringa alpma), or Knots {T. canutus)A but from the motion of the train it was impossible to identify them for certain. A row of posts projected out of the water at intervals near the line on the left side of the train, almost every one of which served as a perch for a Cormorant (.Phalacrocorax carbo ) ; one had its wings extended in the usual attitude assumed by this bird when drying itself in the sun. This habit of perch- ing on posts here seems to have been indulged in from time immemorial, as Salvin saw them sharing the posts with the Ospreys in 1857, and Mr. Whitaker says that they may often be seen in winter at El-Bahira perching on the posts in the shallower parts. Just before we left the vicinity of the Lake we were fortunate enough to see a beautiful flock of some seventy to a hundred Flamingoes standing in the shallow water in a long irregular line, their beautiful pink plumage making a lovely contrast against the blue water. Flamingoes, though not so common as formerly, still frequent both this Lagoon and the smaller one of Sebka es-Sedjoumi to the south-west of the town in considerable numbers during the winter months ; they do not, however, remain to breed here. On arriving at Carthage we began to inspect the ruins; this was a most glorious day, it was quite hot, in fact this was the only really warm day we had during the whole five weeks. We first went into the well-preserved amphitheathre where S. S.

Notes from North - West Africa. ^erpetua and Felicitas and their companions were martyred in he year 203 in the persecution under the Emperor Severus ; lere I saw a large green Lizard, over a foot long, run under some tones; large Grasshoppers with red or green wings, Dragonflies nd other insects were very numerous. We then saw the Theatre, n which a number of Wagtails, apparently Motacilla flava, were lisporting themselves ; I also noticed a small flock of Pipits, vhicli, from their well-spotted breasts, I take to have been i?ithuspra/e?isis, as the Meadow Pipit is a common winter migrant o North Africa. The remainder of the time was spent viewing ome of the other ruins, which are numerous and extensive. A ;>eautiful garden surrounds the chapel of S. Louis; a fine blue Convolvulus was a conspicuous feature, growing over many of he houses and covering fences. Just before sunset we drove 0 the charmingly-situated Arab village of Sidi-bou-Said, and scended the lighthouse 011 Cape Carthage, from which a most xquisite view of the entire Gulf of Tunis was obtained, with a Jorious sunset behind Tunis ; as the Bats were already on the ving, we hurried back to the carriage and drove in the dusk to 'artliage Station. As we passed through a grove of Olive trees flock of birds, about the size of Pigeons, flew by, but it was too ark to see what they were ; and directly afterwards a large light- poking bird, probably an Owl, was caught sight of. At Cape 'artliage I saw a few bright-coloured Sparrows, but, on the whole, 'irds seemed wonderfully scarce. Next morning we visited the Belvedere Gardens, which re situated on the steep slopes of a hill, from the top of which ne views of the Gulf, with Carthage in the distance, can be btained ; the gardens are extensive and contain many fine trees, 'alms, and flowering shrubs : Oleander and Plumbago being in loom everywhere. I watched some Sparrows, which did not eem so chestnut on the head as those in the town ; there were aany birds among the trees, but they were difficult to see. I id, however, get a glimpse of a grey-looking bird, which kept ttering a loud note; I am nearly sure it must have been a Uackcap (Sylvia atricapilla ); the Blackcap can be found here uring the entire year. I afterwards walked up to the Bab Sidi Abdullah, an old gate-way situated in the higher part of the

Mr. T. H. Newman, town ; through the double arches again charming views across the Bay were seen. In cages just beside the gate were two small rather brightly- coloured Goldfinches and a very fine Nortli- African Greenfinch cock, of a beautiful yellowish-green colour. While I was here two Swallow-birds flashed by without giving me time to identify them. In the afternoon I strolled down in the direction of the harbour, passing flocks of Sparrows, which were rather wild ; the cocks had not much chestnut on the head ; they may have been ordinary House Sparrows, but seemed neater than our birds. A number of Gulls were seen in the distance flying over the water. I skirted the shore of the Lagoon, and watched some Waders feeding on a broad mud-flat; I think they must have been Dunlins; among them were two very small Gulls, one being immature, with a blackish band on the end of the tail; they were evidently Little Gulls {Lams minuius'). They did not seem to be feeding; one hardly moved at all during the whole time I was watching; it just stood in the shallow water, the other flew about a little. A few Yellow-legged Herring-Gulls were also flying about. I then mounted a steep stony green hill; small birds were numerous but very wild, I saw one flock in the distance, which must have contained some hundreds of indi- viduals. Everywhere I went the birds seemed wilder than with us, no doubt because so many are shot for eating ; it made it very difficult to make out the species, especially as I am not much used to identifying wild birds. There was a tremendous wind blowing on the top of the hill, which made me not inclined to linger there ; on the very top I saw a large Locust. As I was descending the other side a small dark-grey-looking Hawk dashed round a corner; I expect it was a Merlin (Falco cesalcni), but it might have been a Hobby ; this was the first Bird of Prey I had seen. The 20th was spent in the train ; as we had some eleven hours of travelling to get through, an early start was made and Tunis was left behind at 7.16. At first the country was flat with hills in the distance; soon it became more undulating, with numerous rough bushes, some of which were covered with pink or mauve blossoms ; a beautiful low-growing bright blue Iris was

Notes from North- West Africa. common, as well as other flowers. Presently we came to the Vledjerdah River and kept by it for a considerable distance, it Irst flowed through muddy looking banks, but as we got higher lie country became more wild, the river banks higher and more itony; then we passed through extensive cork forests which cover many acres, and later on the forests which are said to be he last home of the Algerian Red Deer, for by this time we lad passed out of Tunisia into Algeria. About here the line makes >ome remarkable bends, so that the same view may often be seen irst from one side of the train and then the other. A very orilliant sunset was remarkably fine seen over the mountains vitli masses of dark purplish chocolate clouds; we reached Eammam Meskoutine, our destination, about 6 o'clock. During the day I noticed the following birds : just after eaving Tunis we passed close to the inner lake of Sebka es- Sedjoumi, where Waders were flying over the mud flats and several flocks of Flamingoes could be seen scattered over more listant parts of the lagoon. A few small birds, generally in locks, were noticed from time to time flying over the low scrub ; t saw one medium-sized and four small Hawks ; a bird which ooked like a Buzzard flew past while we were having lunch, and ust after we had changed trains at Duvivier, when it was begin- ling to get dusk, a large bird, probably an Eagle, flapped past he station, but on the whole very few birds were seen all day. The 21 st was spent at Ham mam Meskoutine ; this remark- able place deserves a brief description. It is situated on the line )etween Bona and Duvivier ; there is simply an hotel there in connection with the baths, the place getting its notoriety from he wonderful boiling springs of sulphur and iron water, which leposit most curious limery cones wherever they have bubbled ip out of the ground ; some of these cones must be thirty feet ligli, and resemble small extinct volcanoes as they have a hollow ort of crater running down their centres. There are more than me hundred scattered about. At present the hot water, after lowing over some beautiful terraced formation like white marble, >ours down in streams over a great mass of lime-stone and forms he Grand Cascade. Where the water is flowing the rock is of he purest white, but it is stained a rusty red in other places from

Notes from North - West Africa. the iron in the water; dense clouds of steam rise above, and when seen in bright moon-light, as I first saw it, the whole effect is most weird and peculiar. The hot water flows away forming a pebbly stream at the bottom of a beautiful sheltered valley, the steep sides of which are covered with a luxuriant growth of almost tropical vegetation ; in the steamy atmosphere great Palms flourish, tangled thickets of low growing shrubs, mostly thorny, clothe theslopes, clumps of small Bamboos form thickets,Oleander and Tamarisk bushes grow close to the water, and Cyclamens were in full bloom among the rocks. I spent the morning watching the birds ; the valley seems to be a perfect paradise for them, the bushes being full of birds. Many Warblers were wintering here; I think I heard the Chiff-chaff and Grasshopper Warbler, and thought I saw a Wren slip out of a bush I seated myself on a rock where I was partly hidden, but could get a good view of a large part of the valley ; the stream flowed beneath me, while growing on the opposite slope was a tree with many horizontal branches almost bare of leaves, which appeared to be a favourite resting-place for many different species, and I soon began to make the acquaintance of several that I had not seen before. The first bird to show itself was a Goldfinch with a drooping wing, which hopped about for some time among the boulders close to the water; then I saw a Sparrow, and a couple of Tits flew into the tree opposite. At the time I could not quite make them out, but I now believe them to have been the Ultramarine Titmouse (Pains 7 iltra?nari?iusJ a species which I often saw afterwards, it is the North-West African representative of our Blue Titmouse, from which it differs by having the upper parts slaty blue and all the blue portions of the plumage much darker. Then a fine cock Algerian Chaffinch (Fringilla spodiogenys') took up his station on a branch ; it differs from our bird by having the head more slate blue, there is also more of this colour in other parts of the plumage and more green on the back. Then my attention was attracted by a rather loud note and a couple of birds settled on the outer twigs of a bush growing at the top of the slope opposite to me ; I saw they were something I was quite unacquainted with, for though they were soberly attired yet there was some- thing about them which seemed attractive; in size they seemed
Correspondence.

Imost as large as a Starling blit with longer tails, in colour they /ere only dull brown with darker, almost black-looking heads, /hile the pale brown breast faded into white towards the tail, 'his was one of the birds I had been hoping to meet with, as they /ere Dusky Bulbuls (.Pycnonotus barbatus ), a species which is on-fined to this region and which has no European represen- itive ; for some time they sat in full view, thus giving me time b have a-good look at them. This species inhabits wooded and ush-covered localities. Next to arrive was a Redstart-looking ird, which sat on the end of a branch for some little time ; I m not quite sure of this bird, but think it must have been a MLoussier's Redstart (.Diplootocjis moussieri ), a most attractive ttle bird which I frequently saw for certain later on. Then a eautiful cock North-African Greenfinch settled in the tree pposite; the male of this form is much brighter-coloured than urs, and this one looked almost as yellow as a Canary as it sat 1 the sun. The hen, on the other hand, is greyer and duller ian the English bird. Very likely this species, or at least the ocks, would be acceptable over here as exhibition birds. Lastly couple of greyish-looking Sparrows with chestnut-coloured ;rowns came to the tree, and I also saw another of the Redstarts, lackbirds were numerous and often heard, but were so wild that could only catch just a glimpse of one now and then. (lo be continued .) CORRESPONDENCE, NOTES, ETC. THE BLACK-HOODED PARRAKEET. Sir,--I n my note 011 this species in the last number of the Avicultural lagazine , I stated that I had not detected any difference in the plumage of le females of Psephotus cucullatus and P. chrysopterygius. I now hasten > correct this statement, for I find there is a distinct difference. I11 the male of P. chrysopterygius there is a distinct, though faint, yellowish ontal band, whereas there is none in P. cucullatus , so far as I can judge 0111 the material at my command. Moreover the crown of the head in P. irysoptetygius appears to be somewhat darker in colour than in the allied >ecies, which has a greenish tinge over the otherwise greyish crown. I was at first led to think there was 110 difference in the females of :e two species by comparing a specimen in my collection, imported in 1902

Correspondence. or 1903, which I took to be a typical example of P. chrysopterygius , with the female of P. cucullatus in the Zoological Gardens ; and I found them to be identical. This bird was one of a pair recieved alive by Mrs. Johnstone. The male went to Mr. Fasev, who now has it stuffed ; the skin of the female was kindly given to me by Mrs. Johnstone. I have now ascertained the very interesting fact that this pair of birds are typical examples of P<ephotus cucullatus , a species only described last year, although Mrs. Johnstone's birds were imported seven or eiglU years ago. Hence the bird I compared with the living examples of what I believed to be a species new to avicnltnre, was in fact one of the very same species. In comparing the female of the true P. chrysopterygius with P. cucullatus the difference is at once obvious. By the way, the true Golden-shouldered Parrakeet appears to have been extremely rarely imported, in fact I am inclined to think that the eight examples received in London in 1897 are the only living specimens of Psephotus chrysopterygius which have ever reached this country. algorithms.sectionHeader: WILD HABITS OF THE GIANT WHYDAH.
algorithms.bodyText: Sir,--I was much interested by the article by Mr. W. E. Tescliemaker on the breeding of the Giant Whydah which appeared in the January number. I have now been about seventeen years in East Griqualand, and the Giant Whydah is a common bird in most of the parts I have been stationed in, and I am very familiar with its habits. Now the point that particularly struck me in the above article, is that Mr. Tescliemaker expressed doubt as to the polygamous habits of this species; the same thing has often struck me, but I have never been able to prove it. It is usual to read in the text-books that the black males are accompanied by ten or twelve brown females. Now in the spring, when the adult males have already acquired their black plumage, but before they have separated for breeding, these birds are often found in large flocks, which appear to be composed of perhaps two or three males and perhaps twenty or thirty females, but if anyone were to fire into the " brown " of one of these flocks he would probably find that out of the brown birds killed a good half were not females as is usually supposed, but young males of the previous year which had not yet acquired the black plumage, and I think the idea of this species being highly polygamous has probably sprung from the belief that all the brown birds were females. Another point I should like to mention is that, according to my experience, the young males do not attain the full plumage until the second year; but this is a point for aviculturists to decide. I have often seen young males, still in the brown plumage but much larger than females, and
Correspondence.

itli often fairly long (compared with females) brown tails, paying vigorous >urt to the females, and going through the different forms of display, but oking quite ridiculous as they have no beautiful plumage to show off. Another reason for ascribing polygamous habits to this species may ii that the males are very ardent and will chase or display before any male that comes along; but this habit is not confined to this species, but is minion to the whole family, and also to the genus Pyroitielana (Bishop rds) which are not accused of polygamy. Mr.Teschemaker mentions that he does not know the meaning of the affir name for this "I Sakabula it is very appropriate, but is rather hard translate, as it is a compound of the two verbs " saka saka," which literally eans to wave about, like the waving of tall grass, and "hula" which eans to shake, like the shaking of a mat; both refer to the display of the rd and the long waving tail. European names are "Kaffir fink" and Kaffir chief." I quite agree with Mr. Teschemaker that the idea that the ales cannot fly in wind and rain is quite a mistake, as I have often seen em flying about quite happily in sheets of rain, and their breeding season : at the rainiest time of the year; but like most birds with heavy loose tails, 'ey do not like turning their backs to the wind, as they cannot control emselves properly. C. J. Davies.

Sir. --It may interest you to know that I have six young Tliree- iloured Parrot-finches (Erylhrura trichroa)\f\.y\ng about one of my aviaries. The last one left the nest April 6 /h. They are all same size as their \0x25A0rents. * W. R. Temple. THE CRY OF THE SATYRA TRAGOPAN. Sir, -- I should be glad to hear from some of your readers who are iquainted with Tragopans, either in their native haunts or in captivity, as I their experience of the various cries of Tragopans and the meaning of icli. I see in the volume of " Game Birds," in " Lloyd's Natural History," i thing is said as to the various calls of salyra , but Mr. Young is quoted ; saying that m el a nocephalus, when alarmed, utters a series of wailing ties, not unlike those of a young lamb or kid, like the syllables " waa, waa, ua," and that this is louder in the breeding season when it can be heard li'Wards of a mile, and that it is probably to invite females to the spot. The Abbe David is quoted as stating that termnincki gives a very lid cry most nearly imitated by the syllable " 011a " two or three times Ipeated. I have never kept either of the above varieties of Tragopans, but my fperieuce of Satyra Tragopans is: (1) The hen will, when alarmed, at all Usons utter a cry of "quar, quar, quar," something like a duck. (2) The cck is almost invariably silent except in the breeding season. (3) I11 the

Correspojiden ce. breeding season lie at intervals gives utterance to a plaintive high pitched note " bay, bay, bay," like a very young lamb. This is, I think, a call to tilt hen and is only used on days when he is displaying. (4) In the breeding season the cock also gives utterance occasionally to a very loud, boom ing, most weird, unearthly cry "oo-ah, oo-ali, oo-ali," which I take to be? challenge of defiance to the neighbourhood. It is not, I think, to call tin hen, as I have seen the birds together when the cock has given this cry which causes him considerable effort to make. He is then taking 11c apparent notice of the hen. Nothing could be less like his cry when calling the hen than this moaning cry and it is (in the case of my birds) uttered only two or three days each season. When heard for the first time it is verv startling and not easily to be forgotten. I was incredulous at first that il could be the same bird that uttered the plaintive lamb-like cry. (5) The cries of the cock are only uttered by adult birds which have assumed full breeding plumage. C. Barnby Smith.
