Members will, I know, be in accordance with me in wishing show all possible respect to the memory of so good a ruler as r late king, and thus I am sure the illustration which forms r frontispiece this month will be appreciated, representing as does a bird which was named after him when lie was Prince of ales, and has since been imported here and bred to some tent in this country, winning golden opinions wherever it has en kept. It is worth mentioning that his late Majesty on first aring of it, asked if it could be got alive. The Prince of Wales's, or, as I should propose to call it w. the Royal Pheasant, is, as the illustration well shows, one the species or races of which the well-known Colchian or >111111011 Pheasant is the type. It differs from that bird in the ich lighter tone of the plumage, which is of a bright chestnut her than a deep bay, and most conspicuously in its white wing- verts. In the latter point it agrees with the Mongolian (. P . mgolicus ), but that bird is widely different otherwise, especially having a wide white collar and being particularly dark in lour. The h ^.w principalis differs from the Common Pheasant n in being lighter. This Pheasant was discovered by the Afghan Delimitation mmission of 1884, inhabiting grass and tamarisk-jungles in the

The Peaccyyiaker. Bala-Murgliab river; and, what is particularly curious, leading ; semi-aquatic life, for it was observed to be quite at home i; thickets growing in two or three feet of water, and to swim a well as wade in getting from one place to another. Zarudny also states that it always keeps near water whe crowing in the pairing season, for " it drinks and bathes eve during the interval of its crow or song." In bathing at all i would appear to be unique among birds of this family. Its great abundance in the swampy reed-covert, where has been described as rising in places in far greater number than at any battue in England, points it out as a singularly sui able species for our damp climate and often soppy soil ; and the breed spreads it may yet become our dominant type, and af memorial of the late King. And apropos of this, just as I am going to press or member Mr. E.W. Harper sends me the following obituary verse of his own on his late Majesty ; they will, I am sure, meet wit! the sympathetic approval of all of us.

Ube peacemaker. The labourer's task is done; he sleeps! Britannia, bent with sorrow, weeps For her dead King, who ever strove To bind mankind with cords of love. "Goodwill and peace on earth," he sang; And round the world the echo rang ! A slave of duty--he is still At work, when at his window-sill The scythed messenger appears, And bids him mount to higher spheres.
algorithms.author: My Hoopoe.
algorithms.bodyText: By Miss E. F. Chawner. I feel some diffidence in sending these notes for publication, s I am well aware that to generalise on the species when one has >nly one individual under observation is rash in the extreme, 'he re fore, my remark may only be considered to apply to my wn bird, and not in any way as laying down the law. My Hoopoe has been eleven months in my possession, >assed the winter in a partly closed-in but unheated garden aviary, s now robust and in very decent plumage. He was only a few lonths old when I bought him, and I was told that he was doing /ell on an "insectivorous" mixture (some of which was sent /itli him) and would require no other food. This I soon found
algorithms.footnote: 3 be far too roseate a view of the case ; the bird was evidently ot sufficiently nourished, and I saw that he got very little of the ood down his throat, and that it was a difficult matter for him 3 scoop it up. I am a firm believer in the merits of bread-and-
algorithms.bodyText: iilk, so I tried mixing some with the food. The bird ate it oraciously, but it was not a success. He remained thin, took to loping, and neglected himself till lie became so dirty that I was arced to wash him. I gave him all the insects, especially grass- oppers. that I could catch, and I believe these kept him alive. )f course, the miserably wet summer and autumn were sadly gainst him, and every morning I fully expected to find a corpse ffien I came out. One of our members kindly advised me to try scraped meat nd ants' eggs, in addition to all the living insects I could obtain ; e added that he feared it was a case of consumption, and urged le need of warmth. This was very difficult, for when put in a age the bird wore himself out in his endeavours to get out, i have no indoor bird-room) and his dirtiness made him very bjectionable in the house. He would not even try the meat aid ants' eggs ; so, at last, I gave him a daily feed of mealworms, 5 other insects were scarce and hard to find. I changed the lsectivorous mixture for another containing more egg-flake ad dried insects, and found a slight improvement in the bird's audition. I also used to prowl about grassy hedges and banks

Mr. T. H. Newman, with a lantern, whenever the nights were mild, and in this wj obtained a number of various larvae for him. Then I read a letter in the Magazine singing the praises " curd. I tried it the next day on my bird and had the satisfactic of seeing him eat it greedily. From that moment he began i pick up and I had no more trouble with him. He grew live and well-covered, dusted and preened his feathers, grew fres ones where needed, and throve apace. In short, from a pitiab object he became a healthy bird. Curd alone, however, does ir suit, and I find the ideal to consist of a mixture of half curd ai half "food" and a few pieces of scalded bread, all mixed t< aether with hot milk. Mealworms have diminished to six pi diem, and generally some of those find their way into other beal than his. Once he was properly fed cold did not seem to affect hi unless, as once or twice happened, his food was frozen. I sh him into the inner compartment at night and let him please hit] self about coining out by day into a roofed lean-to. Now 1 spends most of his time in the open flight, probing every inch soil. He loves smooth caterpillars and grubs of all kinds, al cockroaches, and eats worms occasionally, but not in any quantit} I am wondering when he will begin to call; so far, exee for a single harsh jarring note when he is frightened or excite he is absolutely silent. Possibly ' he ' is really ' she,'--I cann be positive which.

By T. H. Newman, F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. (Continued from page 223.) - \0x25A0 In the afternoon a small Arab boy guided us up a ste< rocky path for about two miles to see a curious undergroui lake, which became exposed some twenty years ago after a Ian slip. O11 the way back, when exploring some rough rod ground among Olive trees, I flushed a covey of Barbary Pa ridges (Caccabis petrosa ) which, after getting up with a clatt sailed across the valley and were soon lost to sight; I w describe this bird when we get to Algiers, as I brought a pa

zk with me from that place. We passed some more, hot springs, th the remains of Roman baths near, and followed a warm earn back towards the Hotel, on the banks of which Palms d Oleanders flourished. At night, I think I heard Owls, which mded like the distant barking of dogs ; there was a particularly isy kind of frog in a warm pond close by. The country round wild and rocky and affords good sport with Wild Boar and rcupine ; I had some quills of the latter given to me, they ;i often be picked up among the rocks. I was down in the valley again by six next morning, nost before it was light; though many birds were about I saw thing fresh, I heard, however, a Robin-like twitter in some ive-trees, but could not see what it was. We left Hammam eskoutine soon after eight, and arrived at Constantine at mid- y. I only saw a few small birds e?i 7 oute, and a Kestrel poised the air just before we reached the town. Constantine is nous, of course, from its impregnable position, being perched the extreme edge of the precipitous cliffs which form one side the deep and narrow Gorge of the Runnnel, which encircles i town for the greater part of its circumference, the remaining rtion being protected by rocky heights. A wonderful footpath, lied the Chemin des Touristes, overhanging the River Rummel, s been constructed against the face of the cliff all along the >rge, from which fine views of the cliffs can be got ; they rise ep up from the river-bed to a great height. I11 the Gorge were mbers of Rock Doves ( Columba livia ), but many tame Pigeons d joined them ; I saw a number of chequers, several reds, lers with white about them, and one pure white bird. A large lony of Jackdaws (Corvus monedula ) inhabited some holes high in the rocks, close to the spot where the old Roman and the )dern iron El Kantara bridges span the ravine ; Jackdaws are no means common in Algeria, but this is one of the spots lere they are plentiful. Kestrels were very numerous, I had ver seen so many together before ; they kept flying in and out crevices in the cliffs and overhead, uttering their shrill cries, number of Wagtails, probably the White Wagtail ( Motacilla id) were running over the stones in the river bed or flitting out the rocks. Storks and Eagles are said to occur here ; I

Mr. T. H. Newman, saw an Arab collecting some large flight feathers from near tli water's edge, and one or two large birds of prey were seen. The morning of the 23rd was spent exploring the town ; saw several Goldfinches and one rather miserable-looking Ortola (.Emberiza hortulana) in cages. Left Constantine at 1.45 fo Batna, which we reached about a couple of hours after dark ; was quite cold here. Batna lies very high, as it is situated righ in the Allies Mountains ; there is nothing of interest in the tow itself, as it is only a modern French military station, but th marvellous ruins of the Roman towns of Lambessa and Timga can be visited from here, and that was how we spent the 24U We started early to drive to Lambessa ; it was bitterly cole though the sun shone at intervals. On the way we passed a fe\ flocks of small birds, and I first saw Irby's Raven ( Corvus cora. tingitanus ) which is a small race of tlie common species, whic it represents in North Africa. O11 arriving at Lambessa, whe inside the fine square Roman building known as the Prsetoriun: a small dark bird flew noiselessly across and popped into a hoi between two large stones ; I have no doubt this was a Souther; Little Owl ( Carine noctua glaux ); this is a very common bir here and may often be seen in the day-time. Among the ruins first came across Crested Larks; so many forms of these bird occur in this region that I am afraid I cannot attempt either her or elsewhere to define those I saw, but can only call them Creste Larks--these particular ones seemed to belong to a small race I saw several Black Redstarts ( Ruticilla titys ) flying about am perching on the stones, and I watched a small flock of prett little sandy-brown coloured birds which were feeding among, o perched upon, some of the blocks of stones from the ruins ; the must have been Rock Sparrows (Petronia petro?iia). I afterward saw a very fine brightly-coloured cock Cirl Bunting (. Emberiz* chins') perched on the edge of a twig in an overgrown hedge The weather was very cold, and as it came 011 to hail, we wen glad to continue our journey to Timgad, which is about 25 mile from Batna ; it is rather an uninteresting drive through barren looking undulating country. Snow was visible on the higlie Allies Mountains; much ploughing was going on, and I sav some Irby's Ravens following the plough as the Rooks do wit

A T otes from North- West Africa. 233 s. Just before reaching Timgad I caught sight of the black uills of a large grey bird by a small stream, I expect it was a Heron (Ardea cinerea ) ; I also saw several small Hawks. A large lock of Goldfinches were singing in the fruit-trees just outside he ruins; I watched them as they fluttered about while some fere feeding on a grassy bank below. A very fine white Wagtail fas running about by a little stream near the small Museum, yhile what looked like some Tree-Sparrows were sitting on the oof of the building. Among the ruins I came across a pair of Hack Chats (Saxicola leucura ) ; this is a very taking bird, though inly attired in smoky black with the tail-coverts and base of the ail white. As they obligingly perched themselves 011 the top of ome blocks of stone I was able to see them plainly ; they flew o the ground, then up on to a block again. During the night there was quite a sharp frost ; it was a lice bright morning, fresh but not so cold. I took a walk round he outskirts of the town ; Batna is surrounded by a wall for mrposes of defence. A number of Goldfinches were singing in he trees just outside the town: I saw several Ultramarine Tits linging to one corner of the walls and flying about the trees, and presently I encountered two or three brightly-coloured Great fits, which would be referable to the Mediterranean form ( Pams najor excelsus ); they were very tame and hopped about in a hedge >nlv a few feet away from me. On the other side of the town vere many Irby's Ravens, some which were perched in some low rees and let me get near enough to have a good look at them ; jifterwards the}'' flew towards the hills uttering harsh deep croaks nd soared up in wide circles. The commonest birds were Sparrows ; they seemed to be rather difficult to identify; most vere of what I have called the Tree-Sparrow type, the same as hose at Timgad. One, however, seemed to have a very chestnut- floured crown ; some that were near the Great Tits were darker irown and looked looser in leather, more like our House- Sparrows. We left Batna before eleven, at first passing through 1111- lulating country with hills near; a road runs parallel with the ine for some distance, along which numerous caravans of camels nd donkeys were making their way to or from the Desert. I

Mr. T. H. Newman, noticed several small Hawks, many flocks of small birds, most! Larks, and a few Ravens. We afterwards passed some rugge< isabelline coloured country, scarred with dry water-gulleys ; her Chats were numerous. Lastly we came to the district when dates begin to be cultivated, past large groves of Palms, am arrived at Biskra about two in the afternoon. Biskra is situated at the foot of the Allies Mountains, am is just on the borders of the Desert; it is an oasis which, witl others near, forms one of the chief date-growing districts. took a walk through Old Biskra with its mud-built house: " surrounded by beautiful Palms, White Wagtails were ven numerous; I heard and saw a Senegal Dove (Turtur senegalensis fly out of a Palm-tree, for here the bird well deserves its name o Palm-dove, being inseparable from that tree, thus differing ven widely from the habits of the species in such places as Jerusalen and Cairo, where it has become parasitic on houses and builds ii walls and verandahs. The Senegal Dove is verv abundant ii Southern Tunisia and Algeria. Canon Tristram found it com paratively scarce at Biskra in the fifties, owing to its being mucl shot at by the French Officers, but Mr. Whitaker has found i most plentiful here recently, some of the Palms being full o them. Though I was often among the Palm groves I only sav very few, and then only single birds. Next day, the 26th, was a dull cold morning ; we drove t( the oasis of Sidi Okbar, which is sixteen miles from Biskra across the flat mud dried-like Desert, with low shrubs growing a' intervals out of little heaps like ant hills. I noticed many Lark.' and Chats ; as we drove along a flock of large dark-looking birds with long legs and necks, were seen flying in the direction of tht Mountains. I stopped the carriage and got out in order to get r better look at them, they were a long way off; at the time I tool' them to be Glossy Ibises (Plegadis falcinellus ), but it seemec rather a dry district for Ibises, though they may have beei making for some distant marsh or stream ; still perhaps the} were Cranes (Grus grus). Sidi Okbar is a very ancient place and is said to contain the oldest Mosque in Africa; the streets are very narrow, and the sun-dried brick houses so high, tha nothing can be seen from them, but when you mount the lo^
algorithms.title: Notes from North-West Africa .
algorithms.bodyText: ower-like minaret of the Mosque, a wonderful view is obtained ; 11 the distance were the Aures Mountains with Biskra plainly visible nestling at their base, and the level Desert was seen stretch- ng for miles all around with green oases dotted here and there. At our feet, surrounded by a great belt of Date-palms, lay Sidi Dkbar, the flat roofs of the houses all being in full view ; dates md couscouss were drying in heaps 011 many of the roofs. A jeautiful cock Blue Rock-Thrush ( Monticola cyajius) was just help- ng himself to a date from one heap, while a party of Sparrows md House Buntings {Frin gill aria saharce ) were busy further off >ver some couscouss. The House Bunting is a charming foxy- ;oloured little bird, the cock having a bluish-grey head and neck; t is most familiar and tame, and is nearly always found near imnan habitations, being particularly partial to the Arab huts md mosques. It will be remembered that Mr. Meade-Waldo \0x25A0ontributed an interesting paper on this bird in the second 'olunie of our Magazine, p. 52. A Senegal Dove was walking ibout 011 the roof near the House Buntings, and a Starling Sturnus vulgaris') was perched on a Palm frond. I saw two furtle-doves ( Turtur turtur) in a cage, hanging just inside one >f the Arab houses, they were not in very good condition, but eemed to be rather small brightly-coloured birds; this species s abundant as a summer migrant. I took a walk among the ^alms, which are very fine here, and saw what I think was a hen doussier's Redstart. At the edge of the oasis I saw many Crested /arks, which appeared larger and darker-crested than those I lad seen before. O11 the way back to Biskra we passed a large ight-grey bird on the ground ; I much regret I did not stop to lave a better look at it, as it is possible that it may have been a )emoiselle Crane. On the following morning I saw several White Wagtails 11 winter plumage, an Ultramarine Titmouse, and several Irby's lavens in the stony dry river-bed. A Desert Buzzard ( Buteo lesertorum , or cirensis as perhaps it should be called) was flying bout loose in one of the houses in the town ; it was very tame, nd I used to see it when passing, sitting outside on the window edge, looking out into the street ; I believe it was quite full- vinged. The upper surface of the bird is light rufous brown,
algorithms.reference: Mr. T. H. Newman,
algorithms.bodyText: while the head, neck and under surface are creamy-white with sundry dark stripes distributed about the plumage ; there seemed something Kite-like about the bird to me. I11 the afternoon, we went to the hot Sulphur spring, just at the foot of the hills. The spring, which is utilized for baths, is situated in the midst of rough stony ground, with very little vegetation about, though an attempt is made to grow a few Palms. I noticed several White Wagtails and a couple of Starlings, which were rather wild ; in contrast to them was a lovely Pallid Shrike (Lanins elegans ) which was one of the tamest birds I came across ; it flew from Palm to Palm, perching on the very tips of the fronds, as though to be admired. The upper surface is of a delicate French grey, and it has the usual black Shrike markings on the head, while the entire under-surface is white ; it much resembles the Great Grey Shrike, and is confined to the district south of the Atlas Mountains. It is one of the most familiar and fearless birds to be met with ; Canon Tristram noted the habit of perch- ing on the outermost edge of a Palm-leaf over 50 years ago. Next morning, the 28th, large numbers of Starlings were flying about the Palms opposite the Hotel; they were all of the common species. I did not come across the Sardinian Starling which is not uncommon in many places. White Wagtails and Ultramarine Tits were observed on the other side of the Hotel among the Palms growing there. I walked along the dry river bed and saw a party of House-Martins (Chelidon urbica ), probably late stragglers, tempted by the bright sunny weather to linger awhile, as the House-Martin appears only to be a migrant here, wintering further south ; though both the House-Martin and Swallow may occasionally be met with in mid-winter, their presence here then is to be regarded as accidental. Among the House-Martins were a few specimens of the pretty little Crag Martin (Biblis rupestris ) ; this species is resident and may be seen at all seasons; they can readily be distinguished from the Sand- Martin by the absence of the brown band across the breast and by having a white spot 011 all tail-feathers except the middle pair. Though I passed this place at least once ever}'' day during our stay at Biskra, I did not see either species there again. A beautiful Falcon flew along the river course ; it appeared to be dull bluish-

Notes from North- West Africa. 237 grey on the wings, with a whitish under-surface, so it was very possibly a Barbary Falcon ( Falco Barbaras') ; a solitary Raven and some White Wagtails, which seemed to be the commonest birds about, were noticed. I returned through Old Biskra, where I saw a Senegal Dove fly out of a Palm. I11 the afternoon I went for some distance along the Sidi Okbar road, hoping I might again encounter the big grey bird I had seen on the 26th, but I only saw some rather small pale-coloured Crested Larks and the ever present White Wagtails. Next day I visited some Palm gardens just outside the town, where I saw a beautiful cock Moussier's Redstart; it was hopping about in an Acacia bush, and presently flew to the ground, so I could see it well. This lovely little bird is con- fined to the North-West portion of the African continent ; the wings, top and sides of head are black, a conspicuous white band passes from the forehead over the eye, ending in a large patch on each side of the neck, a large alar patch on die secondaries is also white ; the rest of the bird, with the exception of the two central tail-feathers which are brown, is a rich tawny orange. The female is dull brown on head and wings and the under-surface is duller than in the male, fading :o whitish towards the tail. The bird does not seem to be wild, 50 may often be watched from a short distance without showing dgns of fear. I just caught sight of a large bird with black and white wings sailing over the Palm-trees; if it was not an Egyptian Vulture, I do not know what it could have been. Several Ravens and Goldfinches, a very brightly-coloured Sparrow, and two birds that looked like Stonechats (fPratincola rubicola ) were seen, and a solitary Swallow ( Hirundo rustica ) was winging its way to and fro just beyond the Palms. This morning a Jay was seen in Old Biskra perched in a Palm tree: I did not see this bird myself, but it was described to me, and a Jav is a bird which cannot well be mistaken. This would be the Algerian Black-headed Jay ( Garrulus cervicalis ), which differs from our bird chiefly by having a black crest and white ear-coverts and cheeks. I11 the afternoon we drove to the oasis of Chetma. I saw very few birds ; we passed a nice pair of Black Chats, and I think I saw a Senegal Dove at Chetma ; on the way back I got a good view of a Desert Chat

23S Nesting of the Grey-headed Sparrow. (Saxicola deserti). It kept flying along a ditch by the side of the road, appearing some distance ahead and waiting until I got close to it, when the performance was repeated. I saw a stuffed Bee- eater {Meiops apiastcr) in a shop at Biskra; this bird is exceed- ingly abundant through Algeria during the summer months. Barbary Sheep may be obtained in the mountains near Biskra, and Gazelles are common. {To be continued .)

Passer dijfusus. By W. E. Teschemaker, B.A. I am not too sure about the identification of this species-- indeed the African Rock-Sparrows are quite a special study. There is a female of this species (apparently) in the Zoological Society's Small Bird - house at present, presented by Dr. Hopkinson, but labelled Passer simplex. I am under the im- pression that the identification of the Zoo specimen is incorrect, but I may be wrong. Anyway, the subject of the present notice may be described as follows : crown, nape, throat and breast light ashy-grey; back and wings pale brown, median coverts margined with white; rump and tail warmer brown; beak dark horn-colour; irides reddish-brown. Size about that of P. doviesticus. Note a harsh Sparrow-like chirp. Song none. Disposition savage. Habitat (if correctly identified) N.E. and E. Africa. Constitution hard as nails. I extracted four of these Sparrows from a large consign- ment of African birds at Mr. Luer's in June of last year; they are not frequently imported, I think. I turned them out in a small division of the aviary by themselves, and they agreed fairly well until one pair commenced to nest. I rescued one of the non-breeding birds just in time, but the next morning I found in a corner a ghastly object--a thing without eyes, without scalp, without feathers, but still breathing. It was the other unpaired P. diffusus.

They built in a nest-box a domed nest, lined with feathers, ind laid four eggs of a dull greyish ground-colour with reddisli- )rown spots. Size: *75 111m. x '58 mm. Incubation commenced on the 21st July, and I saw young >eing fed on the 1st August. Only one youngster was hatched, )ut this developed into a fine specimen, being fed solely on nsect-food. It was apparently most reluctant to leave the nest --in fact I had it out and examined it once or twice to see if here was anything wrong with it. It finally left the nest 011 the \0x25A05th August, and was then practically as large as the parents ud closely resembled the latter, the only points of difference hat I noted being the colour of the back and beak, the former >eing grey-brown and the latter lighter, The white margins of he median coverts were as distinct as in the adults. The adult hen sat again 011 the 28th August and, when I >arted with all my P. diffusus to one of our members, there was notlier not quite fully fledged youngster which, however, did lot survive the journey. I find that males of this species are rather larger than emales and darker round the eye. I had less trouble with P. diffusus than with any other pecies bred last season, but it must not be taken for granted, I liink, that all Rock Sparrows are equally easy to breed. I have truggled with Petro?iia dentata for five years and have not seen n egg yet.

algorithms.bodyText: A gentleman residing in London, the brother of one of our uembers, recently asked me to come and see an exceedingly rare *ird he had imported from Calcutta--no less than the beautiful 'emminck's Robin ( Erithacus komadori). This is one of the pecies which was first made known through aviculture, it laving been described from caged specimens obtained in apan. For a long time its native home, which is in the Loo- hoo Islands, remained unknown, and even now there are only wo skins of it in the British Museum.

Two Rare Eastern Importations . The illustration, drawn from this specimen, and the note below, will give, I hope, an idea of the cock's appearance; the hen has no black, but is mottled below with grey and white The owner of the bird informs me that it was brought fron Japan to Calcutta by a lascar, and fed on the voyage 011 crushed biscuit moistened with water, so that it is evidently not delicate It is tame and steady, and frequently sings; the note is rich, bu somewhat metallic, and has a character peculiarly its own. Temminck's Robin (Erithacus komadori). Size of our Robin; rich orange-chestnut above, black and white below. I was also shown here an Eastern Nightingale ( Erithacu . golzii) the true Bulbul of Eastern poetry, and distinguished ii India from the very different birds commonly called Bulbuls b> the appellation Bulbul bostha or Bulbul hazar-dastan. As tin illustration shows, it differs from our Nightingale in having 3 decidedly longer tail, and it is also usually much less reddish ii colour, though there is some variation in this respect. algorithms.bodyText: By H. Goodchild, M.B.O.U. *o. I. AN AUGUST HOLIDAY IN THE PENNINES. The two counties of Cumberland and Westmorland possess hree main features in common : they divide the Lake District >etween them, they each have a share of the broad and fertile iden Valley, and both are flanked on the east by that long >uttress of hills, the Pennine Range. The main physical differ* Persian Nightingale (. Erithacus *olzii). hough not equal in sweetness to our bird. A good many of hese birds were formerly imported into India, and fetched a high )rice, but I believe the importation has much fallen off, though ome are evidently still to be had. ipproximates to some extent to the Sprosser, but is more slender uid long-tailed ; in fact, it is the most elegant of the three Nightingales. Like the Sprosser, it is a hardier bird in captivity hail the common Nightingale, and a far more powerful songster,

ence between them is, that whereas Cumberland has a long coas line, the sister county has but an apology for one, in the form 0 the estuary of the Kent and the adjacent part of Morecambe Bay Of the three characters they have in common, the one I an chiefly acquainted with is the line of hills on the east, as at the foot of that I had the good fortune to spend some of my earh years, and to pass many an Autumn Holiday. Uninteresting a? it may look as one passes down the valley of the Eden, and com monplace and featureless in outline as it may appear as viewer from the mountains of the Lake District, in comparison witl them, it nevertheless possesses charms of its own, and it is onh when one explores its deep cut valleys, or " Gills" as the native, call them, that one realises that its want of interest is more apparent than real. Following a holiday taken in the height of the summer o 1908, when weather favoured me to the utmost, I was fortunate in being able to alter the time of my visit this year (1909) tc August and doubly fortunate in that I was there during almos the only spell of fine weather they had, the summer and autumi: through. Leaving Hoddam Castle on the 2nd of August, after hav- ing had the pleasure of drawing and painting some of Mr Brook's superb collection of Malayan birds, I travelled southwarc down the Midland line to a station opposite the highest part o the Pennines, and only about five miles distant from the summit of them. Walking up from the station, I heard, as I neared tin village I was to stay at, a Corncrake grating, this being the onh time I heard the bird, although it is one that is heard all around from the grass fields at Midsummer. Circumstances permitted my commencing my observations at once, and on the Tuesday I made direct for the hills, stopping in the '' fell lane " to make notes of a Wren sitting on a stake in a hedge and carrying his tail level as any other bird might do and to make a sketch of a Whitethroat which I started from a bed of thistles and which flew off looking very much surprised. The dull skies which had prevailed through July were showing signs of brightening, though in the meantime we were fain to be content with merely an absence of rain.

Ornithological Rambles. A Tit was heard but was not seen, so likewise was a Chat of some sort. I was now on the open moorland and might expect to see not only the Meadow Pipit, which abounds on these grassy uplands, but Red and even Black Grouse, although of the latter only a few are about. Two Woodpigeons were seen and a pair of Pipits, but no Grouse of either species. The afternoon was taken up in visiting the cultivated ground to the south of the village and here I found much of the hay still uncut, although it was about a month after they usually begin the hay harvest. In >ne field which was half cut, but in which no one was workin* r \t the time, I saw four Woodpigeons hunting over the swaithes of reshly cut grass. In a neighbouring plantation of Scotch Fir [ saw six or seven Chaffinches feeding together in one of the tees, and not far off recognised the Sand Martin, which in this ^strict only breeds in one place that I know of, viz. in the soil it the top of an abandoned quarry of red sandstone. The Hedge Accentor was seen and the Yellow Bunting heard. A small patch >f primaeval moorland adjoined the plantation, and on this the Curlews bred, I believe, in peace and safety, for I found them ; ery common on it and saw several at once, and also some Pee- vits. This moor contained a very slight green valley, only some en or twelve feet deep and about as many yards wide in its ipper part ; no stream flowed in ordinary times, yet there was a mall pond in it with clumps of rushes growingabout it. On my ast previous visit to this district, in June 1908, a young friend ltd I had gone to this pond towards dusk and had been much uzzled by an object we saw in a clump of rushes growing in the /ater : my friend was the first to guess what it was, and proved iglit. It was a Water-Hen, the only one I ever saw alive in hese parts, which was seeking safety by crouching with its head la amongst the rushes, but which had left its conspicuous white fathers exposed towards the prowling naturalists ; had it gone le other side of the clump and faced towards 11s, only thrusting s head into hiding, we should most likely not have seen it, as ie brown upper surface would have been sufficiently subdued to ave passed for a clod of earth. O11 the present occasion, how- ver, no Water-Hen was seen, but I found two of the large feathers ' the Heron and seaiching around found twenty more, of all

Mr. H. Goodchild, shapes and sizes; I also found feathers of the Cuilew and the Peewit, so it seemed to be a favourite resort with them. On Wednesday, August 4th, there was a high wind and a cloudy sky, and I noticed a Curlew being blown about over the fields near the village. Further out I saw several Chaffinches, all appparently females, hunting over the swaitlies of newly cut hay. Not only many Chaffinches, but two or three Yellow Buntings, a Hedge Accentor and a Redstart came to pick up what they might, and these were soon joined by a Common Wren, a Willow Warbler and an immature Greenfinch. I could not be sure what they were after, but I do not doubt that the finch and bunting as well as the insectivorous birds were searching for such flies and other insects, or their larvae, as were disturbed or exposed by the newly mown grass. P'rom the higher woods, at the foot of the hills, I heard a cry as of a Kestrel, but a long search with the glass, from a dis- tance, failed to show the bird that made it. Just as I was coin- ing into the house at lunch time I heard a Greenfinch singing, in what I put down at the time as " full song." I11 the afternoon I again went over the cultivated ground and cautiously approaching the field where the day before I had seen the Woodpigeons hunting the new mown grass, searched its further parts for any interesting birds it might contain ; in this way I got right up to the fence enclosing it, still prying into its far corners, when suddenly a tremendous whirr sounded almost under my nose and, putting down the binocular, I was chagrined to see a covey of about fourteen Partridges which had beer squatting close to the fence amongst the cut grass, and which 1 might have seen crouching had I only looked close to my teel instead of surveying the distant sides of the field. these Partridges flew over towards our local mill-dam, but although 1 went in pursuit I saw nothing more of them. This dam, being sheltered both by a bank and by trees, was secluded and seemec a favourite spot with Herons, as several times I found theii feathers about it; but this time as I searched round it, I foiluc none. From here I went to the plantation beforementioned, ii the hope of finding Owls or Goldcrests. I saw a Squirrel, whicl sat on a bough about forty feet above the ground, apparent!}

Ornithological Rambles . enjoying a dolce far ?iiente and which took no notice of me though I stared at it with the binocular, and a few Woodpigeons. The only other birds really seen were Chaffinches, although I beard the cheep of birds which I thought must be Goldcrests. Nearly all the feathers found were those of Woodpigeons, but one might have been from a Sparrowhawk's alula, and another, a downy feather from an Owl. In the evening I only heard Green- finches singing and Partridges calling, as I was only out for a short time. On the 1 huisday, Chaffinches and Willow Wrens were seen, and a Great Tit, whose churring notes I at first took for those of a Blue Tit; these on the way to the moorland, where however, I saw no Grouse, but only a few Rooks stalking about, and heard a Willow Wren singing from some trees bordering the highest lying hayfield in the country. A Kestrel was seen hovering near the top of one of the loot hills, about 1,400 feet high ; and three birds I took to be Ravens, but which were nearly a mile off and therefore could not be identified by sound, circled over a small valley at the base of it, while a Peewit was noted on the flank of another steep hill dose by. As I approached a curious flat-topped hill composed )f shale, overlooking the confluence of the two streams mv irother and I most often fished, I flushed a Meadow Pipit from itnong the beds of bracken fern, and arriving at the top about uid-day, sat down to rest. This day proved to be the first of the lot weather we were to enjoy and so unaccustomed was I to teat, that I spent an hour in going a distance of about two miles >ver nearly level though somewhat rough ground, and even lien felt oppressed. From the top ot this hill I searched with my binocular he rough, rushy pastures lying to the South where I knew the flack Grouse nested and saw four birds at a distance of a housand yards or so, which might have been Greyhens, but, lthough I watched the birds closely, I got 110 clue from oinparison with Curlews or Peewits to their actual size, and so itt their identity an open matter. My objective this time was a waterfall in one of our best r *ut streams, where the beck reached fairly open ground after

passing through one of our finest mountain valle\s, distin- guished by the local people as Gurt Deal. My search for the particular waterfall did not succeed and I settled down to make a sketch of another instead. A Kestrel was seen flying over the valley at 1.20, and a pair was seen about 1.30 over a spur of a hill near, and a male in adult plumage came and hovered near me, close enough for me to see with the binocular his tail spreau out like an open fan, and his alert, bent-down head. this bird flew down to the side of the hill I had rested on, and perching 011 the steep side near the top, remained there and pieened. I wicej it flew up and returned before finally leaving. A Cariion Ciow came down the dale and flew backwards and forwards past the most conspicuous limestone crag in the neighbourhood, with something which might have been an egg iu its bill, but dis- appeared over the skyline of the mountain above me without coming near. In the afternoon, a Dipper gave me a chance 0 sketching it, as it perched on a boulder iu a side stream, and ^fter drawing it, I noted four Carrion Crows round the scar when I had seen the one earlier on. Turning my steps homeward I stopped to examine the skyline of the scar in its 1110s prominent part and saw either a Raven or a Cairiou Ciow sitting so that it appeared against the sky. This bird soon began t< preen and I watched it at intervals as long as I remained withii sight. My last item for the day was the flushing of two Partridges seemingly adults, in one of the rough pastures, on my way home. (To be continued). REVIEWS.

Animal Romances, by Graham Rknshaw, M.B., F.Z.S. London : Sherratt and Hughes, 190S. " If vou draw your beast iu an emblem, show a landscap* of the country natural to the beast.iu this work ai attempt is made to present |_animals] as actually living an< moving before the reader.these forewords w r ere writtej on the author's last African trip; it is hoped that some of th

unshine of the wilderness has been transferred to its pages." hiese extracts from the preface of Dr. Graham Renshaw's last olnnie, tell in his own words the purpose underlying the twenty- wo essays that compose it. But it is by no means, only the unshine of the African wilderness that transfuses its pages. He akes his reader from the snows of the Caucasus to the tropics of further India; from East Africa, the last and greatest game 'reserve of the world, to the ice-floes of the antarctic ; from the ntipodes and the coral islands of the Pacific to the prairies of lorth America, and back even to the times of the Mammoth and licient Briton, describing in graphic language and vivid imagery /hat might be, or might have been, seen and heard of the animal fe in the space of twenty-four hours by an individual watcher lone with the beasts and birds. It would be fulsome praise to ay that Dr. Rensliaw can write like Major Eeveson at his best; lit I cannot pay him a higher compliment than by saying that his 00k repeatedly recalls to my mind part of a chapter in " The lunting Grounds of the Old World," where a day in the Indian ingle is described by the pen of a master, stamping indelibly pon the imagination the scenes it attempts verbally to depict. R. I. Pocock. THE JACAMARS. Enera Avium, Conducted by P. Wytsman. Picarice Fain. Galbulidae by P. L. SCUATKR. Brussels, 1909. The Jacamars are related to the Toucans, Barbets and l T o ok peckers, resembling them in many characters besides the iructure of the feet which belong to the type called ' zygodactyl.' although in its strict etymological sense ' zygodactyl ' simply leans with united toes, the term is not applied by ornithologists ) webbed feet but to feet in which the inner and outer toes are irned permanently backwards while the two middle toes retain leir usual forward direction. This type of foot has been in- ependently acquired by distinct kinds of birds, perhaps the est known to aviculturists being the Parrots. It is obviously an daptation to an arboreal as opposed to a terrestrial mode of life, nee birds which possess it are expert climbers but clumsy alkers on the ground.

Reviews. The Woodpeckers and Barbets are widely distributed ; but the Jacamars ( Galbulidee ) and their near allies the Puff-Birds (. Bucconidce ) and the Toucans are only found in tropical or sub- tropical America. The Jacamars recall the Bee-eaters in appear- ance, with their brightly-coloured often metallic plumage and long somewhat-slender bills. They frequent the edges of forests or open glades and feed upon insects. They are not uncommonly found near streams and nest in holes in the banks, dliere are some twenty different kinds known, and these form the subject- matter ot the memoir under notice. Those who are acquainted with Dr. Sclater's scientific papers will recognise in this treatise his happy knack of grasping the essential character of species and of expressing them with a combination of brevity and lucidity which very few authors can equal. R. I. P. INDIAN BIRDS. Being a key to the common birds of the plains of India. By Douglas Dewar. London 1909: John Lank. 6s. net. There has been 110 better book on the fauna of any large area than Blanford's volumes on that of India, but four volumes on birds are a rather large order to carry about, to say nothing of the difficulties beginners find with books like this, and Anglo- Indians and those visiting India will welcome Mr. Dewar's most light and handy work, which is destined to serve as a guide to the larger book, dealing with the commoner species only ; for after these are learnt, as the author says, it becomes easy to locate the rest. The book is most ingeniously arranged, the first part being occupied by keys destined to facilitate birds by some con- spicuous peculiarity of colour, form, note or action. Thus there are lists of crested biids, forked-tailed birds, birds with black heads, birds with yellow, pink, blue, etc., in the plumage, and if the subject of one's search is not identified by means of one ot these keys, there is always a good chance of "spotting'' it with another. I11 the descriptions of the birds dealt with, which follow, the size is estimated by comparison with some very familiar

species, such as the Sparrow and Crow, and these birds of com- parison are indicated by letters ; the Sparrow, for instance being I, while a bird larger than a Sparrow and smaller than a Bulbul goes as IF, and a smaller bird than a Sparrow as --I ; a very ingenious idea. Long tails are treated as extras. No less than 231 species are dealt with, so it will be seen that the work is comprehensive enough, although birds regarded as game are for the most part omitted, such birds, as Mr. Dewar remarks, being usually shot on sight and readily identifiable by other manuals which exist, while his book is intended to facilitate the identification of ordinary, everyday birds by those who have no wish to shoot them. Mr. Dewar points out that it is quite likely that he has omitted some birds which are locally common, but I only miss very few of my feathered acquaintances, chiefly the Blue-cheeked Barbet (Cyanops asiatica ) and the Jungle Mynah {Aethiopsar juscus), while, though my experience of India was far less wide than his has been, I have come across most of the kinds he mentions. I think, therefore, he has covered the ground completely, and I recommend his book to all who wish to take tip the study of what I am convinced is the most interesting avi- fauna of the world, if only because it has been less disturbed by man--in spite of an ancient civilization--than any other. F. F. THE VERTEBRATE FAUNA OF CHESHIRE AND LIVERPOOL BAY. Edited by T. A. Coward, F.Z.S. 2 vols. illustrated. London, 1910, Witherby & Co., 26s. net. The bird section--with which alone we have here to do-- }f this beautifully-produced and exhaustive work is by Messrs. I'. A. Coward and C. Oldham, F.Z.S., M.B.O.U., authors of 'The Birds of Cheshire," and is replete with interesting in- clination, the outcome of careful and conscientious observation, :he food and habits of the birds receiving especial attention. Cheshire is favoured by the presence of an unusual number }f interesting species, and the authors have utilized their opportunities of observation to the full. It is particularly pleasant to read of a Grey Phalarope being observed at intervals

2 5 0 Reviews. of ten days, instead of being killed as usual, and one interesting note on it was that it took food when on the wing as well as when swimming. It is interesting to read that that grand bird, the Canadian Goose, is breeding freely in a perfectly wild state on Cheshire waters, and that flocks of hundreds may be seen at times in winter. This bird will at this rate, probably have to be put on the game list shortly if it is not treated in this way already, for geese in abundance are not bv anv means friends of the farmer ; but we could very well do with it as a game species. An observation to the effect that two domesticated Shel- drakes were killed by foxes is worthy of notice, in view of the statement made by a continental author that Sheldrakes will nest in Foxes' earths even when Reynard is in occupation. It is evidently no repugnance to the flesh of this bird, unpalatable as it to most people, which causes this forbearance if the story is really correct. Another interesting note concerns the persecution of a Pied Flycatcher by one of the common spotted species; if this is usual it may explain why the former bird is so local in this country, but the relations of allied species to each other, although probably of great importance with regard to geographical dis- tribution, have been but little worked out. The book is full of suggestive observations such as these, and I cordially recommend it to all members. F.F.

algorithms.bodyText: By Frank Finn. London : Hutchinson & Co., 1910. Price 5/- net. The above title has been given to a very handy volume which Mr. Finn has added to his series of useful handbooks. In size it is not too large to carry in the pocket, but it contains an enormous amount of useful information to the student of British m Birds' nests and eggs. There are about thirty plates of eggs, of which the majority are coloured by the three-colour process direct from the eggs themselves, the finished illustrations being very true to nature, though we think the appearance of the plates is somewhat

narred by the dark-coloured background that has been adopted. .Vhite and plain-coloured eggs have been figured by ordinary hack and white plates. Turning to the text, we find a description not only of the lest and eggs of each species, but the birds themselves are lescribed, an excellent arrangement since, in many cases, to atisfactorily identify eggs one must first be able to see and dentify the bird that laid them. The arrangement of the species is somewhat unorthodox ; nstead of the recognised systematic order being followed, the )irds are arranged in groups such as " In Towns and Gardens," ; By Wayside and Woodland," " By the Waterside," and so forth. L'liis arrangement has something to commend it in the present >ook, which is intended, we take it, rather for the beginner than or the experienced naturalist, though even in this case it is oubtful whether the recognised system would not have been ireferable. We cannot agree with the author when he says that pro- iably any of our lost breeding species might be restored by rtificial introduction. Doubtless this would be beneficial with uch species as the Kite, as the few remaining pairs in Wales, its ist stronghold in Britain, are very in-bred, and the introduction f some new blood from abroad might give the species a new iase of life. But in the case of the majority of disappearing British birds, their threatened extermination is due to cultivation nd drainage, and the reintroduction of such species would be ntirely useless. With these few comments we leave the book to our readers 'ith the assurance that they will find it an exceedingly useful ddition to their libraries. D. S.-S.

y Mary Blair Beebe and C. William Beebe. Henry Holt & Co., New York, 1910. $2. 75 cents, net. In this handy and beautifully-prepared volume, illustrated y numerous photographs, our member, Mr. C. W. Beebe, and is wife relate their adventures and observations in out-of-the- ay parts of tropical America and its islands, Trinidad ; Vene- lela, and the little-known interior of British Guiana. In the

Reviews. first locality they stayed at a settlement on the renowned lake of pitch, one of the wonders of the world, and in the latter enjoyed excellent opportunities of studying the Hoactzin (Opisthocomus hoazin ) and would no doubt have succeeded in introducing this most remarkable bird to aviculture, had not Mrs. Beebe had the misfortune to break her wrist by a fall from her hammock, which necessitated an immediate abandonment of the expedition. Fortunately the accident had no serious consequences, Mrs. Beebe having made a rapid and complete recovery. The book is replete with observations of the greatest interest, not only on birds, but on beasts, on reptiles, fish, insects, and the local types of humanity. Many of the birds dealt with are, of course, familiar to aviculturists, such as Toucans, Parrots, Hang-nests, Tanagers, and the various South American Finches ; and the accounts of these will be read with especial eagerness and interest by those of our members who are wise enough to acquire this book. Many birds were secured for the New York Zoo by the expedition, and interesting accounts are given of the methods of capture employed ; the following, for instance : " A cage containing a Yellow-bellied Calliste was one day placed in a tree about twenty feet high, and limed twigs arranged on neighbouring branches. In two hours in 'the morning, two specimens of the same species, three Blue Tanagers, two Black- faced Callistes, two Toua-touas or Brown-breasted Pygmy Gros- beaks, and one Yellow Oriole were taken. The various species of Tanagers and Orioles are much more gregarious in feeding habits than the Finches, hence the variety caught. The Toua- touas were purely accidental visitors. The Finches are rarely taken by a call-bird not of the same species." Mention is wisely made of the difficulties in catching in the tropics, owing to the liquefaction of bird-lime by the mid-day heat, which is also dangerous to the call-birds. Among the appendices is a very useful one giving the native Guianan names of birds, and the descriptions often given of the various birds mentioned in the text are so good that any aviculturist going to these regions armed with this book would be able to recognise many at all events of the new friends he would meet with. F. F.

"The British Warblers: A history with problems of their lives." By H. Eliot Howard, F.Z.S., M.B.O.TJ. Part IV. London : R. H. Porter, 7, Princes Street, Cavendish Square, W. Price 21/- net. The fourth part of Mr. Eliot Howard's beautiful work on le Warblers is now published and is in every way equal in ualitv to the three preceding parts. The species dealt with are le Whitethroat, Lesser Whitethroat, Greenish Willow Warbler nd Siberian Chiff-chaff. Five excellent coloured plates and six hotogravures, all by Henrik Gronvold, are well up to the andard of those of the previous parts and add very materially > the value of the work. Never has a book been written in which the life-history of group of birds has been more fully treated than in the present istance, and the author introduces his readers to many habits id problems in the lives of this charming group of migrants hich will be quite new to most people. The author is undoubtedly a rare good observer, and from le day of the arrival of a Warbler in his neighbourhood, he irefully notes its habits. In the case of the Whitethroat for stance, the males precede the females by several days as a de. Each male takes possession of a certain territory, and mietimes even constructs a nest in readiness for the female qon her arrival. Severe battles take place between individuals the same sex if they cross one another's boundaries. The irious attitudes of display, courtship, and so forth, as revealed the reader of Mr. Howard's book, are highly interesting and ftraordinary. The species dealt with, with the exception of one or two, hich can only be regarded as rare stragglers, are all treated in e same thorough style, nothing of any importance in their :onomy having apparently escaped the author's observation. D. S.-S.

algorithms.bodyText: Sik, (i) Nesting of the Pintaieed Whydah. Dr. Butler having asked me to obtain some further particulars of the event mentioned in my notes on Chera progue, I wrote to our member, Air. W. T. Page, who inspected the aviaries in question shortly after the young were said to have left the nest. Mr. Page has very kindly written me as follows:--" The facts are simply these. The roof of Mrs. A.'s aviary was covered with spherical nests of Weavers, Whydahs and Finches: she pointed to quite a group of nests close together--all of one character, i.e. merely spherical. Mrs. A. said at the time her impression was at first that the parents were Finches, but, among a crowd of birds, I thought the evidence too inconclusive and did not bring it forward, as afterwards she saw the Pintails feeding. Practically the only intimation she had of them was seeing the young--in fact the nests were so thickly placed undei the roof among the branches, in husks, travelling cages and the like that it would be most difficult to locate the young." The original reference to this occurrence may be found in Bud Notes, Nov. I 9 * 9 > P- 2 57 * I fear the above data do not throw much further light on the interesting question of the alleged parasitic habits of this species which Dr. Butler has referred to. It will be noted that the owner first thought the young were being fed by Finches and subsequently by the Pintails. It is not probable that both these observations can be correct, and. it one is incorrect, then both may have been so. A possible explanation of the matter is that the Pintailed Whydah may only be occasionally parasitic, and this hypothesis would not of course be disproved by the fact of its rearing its own vouim in an aviarv (even if the fact were well attested) because, under these unnatural conditions, the parents might not easily find a suitable host. It should be noted that Haagner in his latest work ap- parently accepts Austin Roberts' statements as conclusive, although lie must of course be well acquainted with Stark's and Shelley's description 01 the nests and eggs (cf. Sketches of S. African Bird Life p. 72). I am not in any way opposed to Dr. Butler's view : all that I wish to point out is that I do not think he is justified in saying (p. 134) "if no Waxbills were present in the aviary in which the Whydahs were bred the only suggestion of Mr Roberts which now remains to be disproved is the character of the eggs. We have evidence that some young Pintails were bred in an aviary, but not as to how they were bred, and, further, according to Haagner (I have not seen the original paper) Roberts did not say that this species was parasitic only on Waxbills.

The question of the colour of the eggs, however, ought to be easily ettled by an aviarist and, if it can be shown that they are not white, then *f course Roberts' observation is ipso facto discredited. Why does not Dr. hitler settle this question once and for all by breeding this species? He
algorithms.listItem: * as leisure, suitable aviaries and more experience than any of us. ii) The Br.UE Grosbeak.
algorithms.bodyText: Perhaps I may be permitted to add a postscript to my recent notes on his species. On nth Feb. I caught up the young male and examined it are fully. It had only two very small blue feathers on each side of the hroat--so small as almost to require a magnifying-glass to see them. As his bird had an extensive, and apparently natural, moult in October last his fact marches well with my suggestion that the young of this species do ot assume the adult plumage till their third season. It has not sung as yet. iii) The Giant Whydah. The young male of this species went through an extensive moult in November, casting the whole of his tail, many of the flights and some of he body-featliers. Towards the end of the mouth I first heard him sine-- ag, and he has continued to do so at intervals throughout the winter. The ong is not so loud as that of an adult male, but of the same character. The ong itself and the attitude of the singer, with quivering and partially out- pread wings, are essentially Weaver-like. 14th May.--I have been much interested in Mr. C. J. Davies' letter in he May issue re the wild habits of the Giant Whydah, and am glad to find hat his observations lead him to agree with my suggestion that this species lay not be always polygamous. If someone could tell us what [numerical] roportion the females really bear to the males in an ordinary flock in the 'inter one would be better able to form an opinion. The fact that so very iw females are imported might lead one to suppose that the females are ctuallv less numerous, but a correspondent who trapped and imported Dine Giant Whydahs wrote me that the explanation of the scarcity of nported females is that the males perch in conspicuous places 011 bushes, nd are therefore easily taken with bird-lime. He found it impossible to atcli any females because the latter always took shelter in the long grass. It would be a very interesting experiment to test the alleged polygamy f this species bv associating two males and two females in one aviary. Our lember Mr. W. Willford purchased my adult male and the adult and young miales, and it is just possible that in the large division of his aviary, which understand is no less than fifty feet square, the adult male might tolerate le presence of his son and heir. I atn keeping the young male to ascertain t what age he may come into colour and, should he do so this summer, I lall have no further use for him and shall be only too pleased to present iin to Mr. Willford for this purpose. I may here mention that this young male has lecently succeeded in

Correspondence . learning the song of the Blackcap, which is certainly quite the oddest imitation in the way of bird song that I have ever come across. I may also mention that on the 6th May when I had occasion to catch him, he tried very hard to frighten me by emitting the loud hissing Weaver-ish note which, as I have already pointed out, adult males adopt as a means of defence. I am glad that Mr. Davies has at last given us an authoritative trans- lation of the native name, Isakabula , because I have at various times come across no less than three versions, each quite different. (iv) The Rufous-backed Mannikin. I kept some of the young in a cage in my sitting-room for some time to see how they assumed the adult plumage. All those hied in the early part of the summer completed the change in one month (except as to the colour of the beak and a few of the primaries) but one bird bred towards the end of the season has retained a kind of intermediate plumage, the head not having become black. I find that they undergo a complete moult of everv feather except as to the back from the neck to the mmp. Heie, however. I could detect no sign of a moult, although I handled them con- stantly, and yet the shade gradually changed from mouse-colour to rich, dark chestnut. I can only conjecture that in this case there was an actual change of colour. Isay " I conjecture " because I know that many have denied the possibility of such a change, and it would certainly be most difficult to prove. W. K. 1ESCHEMAKER. A .SUGGESTION. Sir,--A s the satisfactory cageing of Eagles, Vultures, etc., has for long been a matter of much difficulty, I venture to put before you a sug- gestion which, doubtless, many will consider a mad one, though nobody can deny it would be novel. Most readers are familiar with the tape-measure that winds itself up by a spring when released, after having been pulled out to its full extent. Could not the same principle be applied bv tethering an Eagle or Vulture in the open, so that it could have the space to fly aloft ? The length of flight could be controlled by the amount of cord wound on the cylinder, and the strength of the spring, in conjunction with the weight of the rope, could be so arranged that the bird would be unable to pull it out to its full extent, and so receive a severe check in mid-air. On returning to earth, the coil of cord would automatically wind itself up. To prevent the bird from severing the cord and to give it a certain amount of freedom when 011 the ground, t would be necessary to have several yards of strong but light chain fixed to the end of the cord, with a button or some kind of stop, placed at the junction to prevent the chain becoming wound up 011 the cylinder. E Z. S.

Watford, Herts. - MR. FROST IN DEMERARA. . Most of us have probably read of our member Mr. W. Frost's safe "tum to Demerara in our press, but the following from the Deme) ara laity Argosy for April iotli, kindly supplied by Mr. F. W. Harper, will be f interest, no doubt. Mr. Wilfred Frost has just returned from his journev into the iterior in search of the beautiful bird that occurs there, the "Cock of the ock." He has succeeded where others have failed, for he has brought ack with him six living specimens. Their capture, however, entailed a ist amount of labour and hardship, and at times there was even danger to fe and limb. All. 1 lost, who is big and stalwart, and possesses the true spirit ot ie hunter, is the representative of the well-known naturalist, Sir William lgram. Some months ago, he brought "Birds of Paradise" from New uinea to I obago for Sir William, and at the beginning of Januarv he nnmenced his quest of the " Cock of the Rock," only stuffed specimens which are to be seen in museums. He was accompanied by Mr. Alfred 'inter, who has spent many years in the interior, and, therefore, was in i excellent position to act as guide and general adviser. 1 he destination of the party was the Merrimai range of mountains, iiis is where the "Cock of the Rock" abounds, and the party were rtunate in getting there just at the time the birds were nesting. This ade their capture easier, but, all the same, it was not achieved without me difficulty, the birds being extremely shy. A number were caught by e Buck Indians, but they died, and the six brought to Georgetown were ptured by Air. Frost himself, who is an expert in the art of bird-catching. The journey into the interior was toilsome and trying; but. the return urney with the birds was even more so. For days at a time, the party's ogress was stopped by forest swamps, which because of the heavv rain, se almost breast high. Then, the bush was almost impenetrable at parts, d the greatest difficulty was experienced in getting along. By water the ual danger was incurred when the numerous falls were taken. On one casion, the Buck Indian at the bow of the boat, fell overboard, but

The Societys Medal. managed to swim ashore at a point lower down. At another time, the party's boat ran on to a submerged buoy and stuck. The Indians. swamj ashore, and attempted to pull the canoe off by means of a rope. As they pulled, the boat tilted over, until the water poured in. At this, Mr. Frost, who had been holding down the cages in order to prevent them toppling over with their precious prisoners, sprang out on to a log, thinking, to use his own significant phrase, that "all was up." This action apparently was all that was required, for the boat floated off, and Mr. Frost got inside a&alll *Mr. Frost speaks with pleasure of his experiences in an Indian village. This consisted of two long houses, and into one of them Mr. Frost and liisj party went without any ceremony whatever. The occupants were some.I what surprised, but they soon made the strangers " feel quite at home," and treated them in the most hospitable manner all the time they remained. Mr. Frost describes the house or hut as very dark inside, there being ncj windows. The roof was low, and, as Mr. Frost stands 5 feet 10 inches in liis stockings, he could never stand erect when within doors. The inmates were kindness itself, sharing generously whatever food was going--and there was plenty of it, game being very plentiful. 'I have never comt across a better lot of people than the Indians I met with there.' That is Mr. Frost's tribute to them ; and Mr. Winter says it is certainly deserved." THE SOCIETY'S MEDAL. Mr. W. E. Teschemaker now has a claim to the medal for breeding the Grey-headed Sparrow (Passer diflusas).

By J. Lewis Bonhote, M.A., F.L.S., F.Z.S. So little is known of the normal limit of age in birds, and .cmate observations lelating to the age attained are so meagre, lat it is hoped that these short notes, for the accuracy of which can vouch, may be not without interest. I have kept birds ive since 1893. I 11 1896, however, my aviaries were broken up id, with the exception of two individuals which I was after- ards able to trace, I have been unable to follow the subsequent reer of any of my former birds. I11 1899, on my return from *road, I again started my aviaries, and since then I have, as fore, kept accurate records of all my birds. These notes erefore show the age to which certain species can live, but in > case can it be said that they show the normal length of life, r, with the exception ot one drake of eleven years, to which Terence will be made later, none of the birds still living show > ns of old age, and I cannot recall a death which could be :ributed definitely to that cause. My notes on the small birds are remarkably scanty, as, dng to the difficulty of identifying any particular individual, :ords of their deaths were not kept. We know, however, that uiy pet finches have lived 15 to 18 years, doves also reach from to 20 years, and a few records of Gulls, Owls and Parrots run 11 higher. In looking through these notes care must be taken not to neralize, as the average of age in the different families may be

Mr. J. Lewis Bonhote, largely due to their adaptability to confinement. For instance, most of the Waders seem to die after two or three years, and il might be presumed that they are normally short-lived, till we also note that one Oystercatcher has lived seven years and three months and is still living in splendid health and condition. For the rest, the notes tell their own story. No records (with one or two special exceptions) of less than a year have been taken, and in spite of their admitted imperfections, I hope other readers may be induced to give us some of their records as only by an accumulation of accurate facts can we hope for definite knowledge. Short notes on the breeding and management of many ol the species have also been added in the hope that they may
algorithms.listItem: prove useful to others. 1. Song Thrush ( Turdus musicus). 5 years 5 months and 4 years ; both still living. This species has nested and hatched in confinement, but owing to insufficiency of live insect food the young wen not reared. Both the Continental and English forms of this species have been kept and retain their distinctive shades ol colour. 2. Redwing ( Turdus iliacus). 1 year 2 months. This is the only example of this species I have ever kept. 3. Robin ( Erithacus rubecula). 1 year 3 months. 4. algorithms.bodyText: be found were it given a large place in which to fly. The one I kept had the use of a large barn from October on- wards but was not strong enough to complete its moult the following summer. Birds of prey, without exception, are delicate in confine- ment, and to do well and keep in good plumage want care and attention. They should not have butchers' meat more often than necessary, should be fasted on at least one day a week and be given rats or birds also at least once a week, if fresh and warm so much the better. They should ?iever, in my opinion, have an open-air flight, but the aviary should only be open 011 one side and should face the dryest and warmest aspect. Water to drink or in which to bathe is by no means essential. They should never be given more to eat than they can finish at a meal, but on the other hand they must not get too hungry before their next meal. Their appetite varies with the seasons, and they require more generous feeding in autumn than at other times of year. If these points be watched, however, the careful aviculturist will find no great difficulty in keeping them in health and beautiful feather. The ' Kestrels' House ' at the Zoological Gardens, although in bad repair, is to my mind a model house for Raptores, and the condition of the birds in it at the present time will bear out my contention. It is. however, doomed to destruction and will, I fear, probably be replaced by a more pretentious, but certainly not more suitable, building.

algorithms.bodyText: survived their first winter. In confinement this is a hardy bird once it is acclimatised, but they require careful watch- ing during their first winter. They will do well in an open aviary, but must have a good shelter into which they can retire in bad weather. My herons are always fed entirely on fish ; they will not do well on butcher's meat, though if it be given they will take it in preference to their more natural food. As they are comparatively sedentary birds they are apt to get corns on their feet from continual perching on the same spot. This may be obviated by tying small twigs of varying sizes on the perches so that the birds never get exactly the same grip. Perches must of course always be provided, and herons should never be pinioned. 45. Night-Heron (. Nycticorax griseus). 9 years 7 months and 4 years 10 months. Two examples.
