algorithms.bodyText: /hen they arrived I could not find any blue thrush about them ut a good deal of blackbird : however I arranged to keep them 5 I had not heard of them being imported before. They were ither dirty, but otherwise in fair plumage for newly imported irds, and it was not until they had done a good deal of bathing lat I was able to make out any difference in the two birds, hey both looked a dull black, each had a yellow beak and allow legs, but the colour of the latter not so pronounced as the ills. It was not before I turned them out that I could distin- uish any difference in the plumage. The cock is black, but not ich a good colour as our common blackbird. The hen can be escribed as a brown black, but at a distance, it is not easy to tell le sex except that the cock has a yellow iris round the eyes. 11 Sclater's "Argentine Ornithology" they are described as Uniform brownish black, bill and feet yellow : total length 11*5 iches, wing 5*3 and tail 4*5. Female similar." I11 fact it was 'om this description that I was able to class the birds. It is lere spoken of as being " Very common at Mendoza, Cordova,

Nesting of the Argentine Blackbird. Tucuman and met with among the shady trees of the prom- enades : lias a better song than onr blackbird, which is heard at a distance, especially in the evening." The whistle is distinctly loud--they have both a call of two short and one long note, but none of the wretched war-cry of our common bird. On February 4th, I noticed the hen going with open bill at the cock and driving him round the cage ; in fact, she gave him no peace at all, so the next day, Sunday, being fine and mild, I decided to turn them out in a fair-sized aviary, 40ft. by 20ft. and 14ft high, which is in a sheltered position. They seemed to enjoy the change and soon settled down. O11 the 18th March I saw the hen carrying dried grass into a nest-box made out of an old cartridge box with two boards inverted, V-shaped, forming the roof, and hung on the side of the aviary in the open. O11 the 19th the hen was 011 the nest, so 011 the 20th I took a ladder into the aviarv and found two eggs in the nest. The next day the third egg was laid which appears to be the usual clutch. I did not remove the eggs but saw thev were about the usual size of Blackbirds' eggs, but more like a Missel Thrush's in markings. The hen sat steadily, only coming off to feed. O11 the morning of April 2nd, I noticed the hen breaking up her mealworms, so I concluded she had not sat in vain. The next day I looked in the nest and found two young hatched and the last egg chipping, so by that she must have started sitting from the laying of the first egg. So far all had gone on swimmingly, because I had had nothing to do with it-- the birds had done it all. Now the work was to be co-operative, and it remained to be seen if I could rise to the occasion. About this time the weather was much colder than when I turned the birds out and upon going to the aviary, on the morning of the 4th, my hopes of a medal dropped to zero, for the head of one young one was hanging out of the nest. However, upon looking into the nest, I found the other two alive, one much bigger than the other in fact; I should say the first and last hatched. From now until the birds left the nest I was kept well on the trot. I looked again on the 5th and found all well, both old birds feeding steadily. On the 17th they had very little down left on them and upon going

Notes from North-West Africa. ito the aviary on the 19th, I found both young ones on the round, one still a little larger than the other. The young birds ave black bills with lighter tips, the legs flesh-colour. The ody is dark brown, the throat and breast lighter, the feathers ave ashy tips which gives them a speckled appearance. By the 23rd the hen had re-built the nest and laid two ggs ; the next day she laid the third. This nest I robbed for two easons. First, I thought the old birds would neglect the young nes, and secondly I wanted the eggs to examine. They have a ale green ground-colour, splashed and dotted all over with rich ark brown, but more particularly at the large end. They vary 1 size, the largest egg is i 3 \ by H. O11 the 27th, I saw one of the young ones feeding at the oft food dish for the first time, but the old birds continued to ied them until about the 7th May. At the time of writing the two young ones look as large s the old birds, and another clutch of eggs have hatched and ae young are feathering nicely. If the three blown eggs will be of any interest to the luseuin, I shall be glad to send them.

By T. H. Newman, F.Z.S., M.B.O.U. f Co?icluded frojn page 23S). We left Biskra on the morning of November 30th for the hort journey back to El Kantara ; on the way I noticed a large ock of what appeared to be Pigeons--very likely Rock-doves-- nd a couple of Ravens. El Kantara lies high, and is situated ight in the Aur&s Mountains ; it consists of a remarkable gorge f rugged rocks through which the El Kantara River flows. It las been styled the Key of the Desert, and forms the first of the ases, being the most northerly point for the culture of dates; jaany thousand Palm trees grow beyond the Gorge, among which re three Arab villages. The first birds I noticed were some Ultra- aarine Tits in some fruit trees in the garden of the little Hotel; aany Sparrows were flying about the road. I11 the afternoon I

Mr. T. H. Newman, walked through the Gorge towards the Palms, and got a good view of a fine cock Blue Rock-thrush sitting on the edge of a Prickly- Pear leaf; presently he flew to the top of a mud hut, flitting his tail upwards much as a Blackbird might do. A Black Chat and a cock Moussier's Redstart were next seen hopping about in company ; also Crag Martins and the ubiquitous White Wagtail were in evidence, while from high up the mountain side the hoarse croak of the Raven could be heard. I11 the dining-room of the Hotel were two stuffed Rollers ( Coracias garrulus ), a species which is very plentifully distributed during the summer months, but it has never been my good fortune to meet with it alive, except in captivity; also a large dark Eagle Owl, doubtless referable to the North African form Bubo ascalaphus. In another room were four Houbara Bustards ( Otis undulata), one being a very fine bird ; a Night Heron (. Nycticorax griseus), and a Chough (Pyuhocorax graculus). Canon Tristram found this last species breeding here in 1857, so it 1S probably still to be met with here, though I did not see any living birds. December 1st was a nice bright morning : it was quite cold and there had been a sharp frost in the night. During the morning I only noticed some Crag Martins and Sparrows, and I was glad again to see the House Bunting in one of the Arab villages. Later in the day I saw two Black Chats sitting 011 a low wall near the river; they have a noticeable way of jerking the tail upwards, and the white patch at its base is very con- spicuous during flight. A Cirl Bunting, some Ultramarine Tits and hen Algerian Chaffinches were also observed. The Blue Rock-Thrush must be very abundant here ; I saw three dart out together near one of the villages ; the second bird was making dives at the leader, while the third followed a little way behind; they quickly turned and disappeared behind a wall. The next morning was rather warmer. I saw nothing fresh, but a couple of Ravens at pretty close quarters--one was soaring round and round uttering hoarse caws--a hen Moussier's Bed- start perched on a cactus, and a Blue Rock-Thrush. Left El Kantara before 10 ; a little way beyond Batna, a man got into the train who had evidently been shooting by some neighbour- ing water ; he had a number of Teal (. Nettium creccd), and other

Notes from North-West Africa. )licks ; also a fine Black-winged Stilt (Himantopus himantopus'). *mall birds were numerous ; I noticed two Kestrels and four ,apwings, and I caught sight of a grey bird which I thought light be a Harrier ; the Pallid Harrier ( Circus macrurus') is said ) be the commonest species to be met with; it is, however, ifficult to make out birds clearly from a moving train. As we ad nearly an hour to wait at El Guerrah, I walked up a steep icky hill close by but only saw a Grey Wagtail (Motacilla \elanope) and some White ones near a small stream, also some ,arks. Arrived at Setif about 7.30 in the evening ; there is othing of interest in Setif, which is only a modern commercial )wn. We left it by motor next morning; at first travelling irough fertile land with hills 011 either side, gradually the hills icame more and more steep and rugged and closer to the road ; j" we approached Kerrata, where we stopped for lunch, I saw >me Ravens, and three beautiful Kites {Milvus viilvus) were seen irly near, gliding up the valley. I know of no bird more scinating to watch on the wing than a Kite. A Kestrel and a rger Bird of Prey were also seen, and a number of small birds; flock of Rock-doves were flying along the river bed at Kerrata. 11 resuming our journey, the scenery at once became most and, the road, which descends all the way from Setif, now :irted round magnificent rocky heights and wound in and out a wonderful way along the side of a pebbly stream. This is e famous Chabet Pass, which would certainly be hard to beat r grandeur anywhere. After passing through the Gorge, the \0x25A0untry again becomes more open, the hills become clothed with ees and shrubs ; 011 the lower slopes grow fine cork trees. Soon impses of the sea are obtained; Olive trees appear; many dms, Plantains and other fruit trees are grown ; and you pass rough extensive vineyards; then the road skirts the Gulf of >ugie. It is extremely pretty as you look down first 011 the blue iter, then across to Bougie nestling at the foot of the green )pes of a hill jutting out into the sea and forming one arm the Bay. We reached Bougie just before dark; it was much ilder here. The 4th was a bright summer-like day. I11 the morning I

Mr. T. H. Newman, walked out as far as Cape Carbon ; the steep path runs above the sea, while on the other side is a dense tangle of scrub, prickly oak and other shrubs, among which a fine heath three or four feet high was growing, ranging in colour from pure white to deep pink; behind rose high rocks. This scrub was full of birds which were, however, very wild and dived into cover as one approached. I heard Blackbirds, and by watching saw some Tits, probably^ Ultramarine, but they may have been Mediterranean Great Tits; Blackcaps were very numerous. I saw two greenish- brown Warblers, apparently belonging to the genus Hypolais , blit I could not make out the species; a Black Redstart, and some Chaffinches, Algerian I expect. Ravens were heard high up among the rocks. On the way back I detected a Tree-creeper on the trunk of an Olive tree; the North-West African bird is rather darker in colouration than ours ; it has been given the name of Certhia familiaris brachydactyla on account of its some- what shorter hind-claw. In contrast to the other birds were some Serin Finches, which several times flew into the tree under which I was standing; this charming little bird reminds me rather of a Siskin in the way it balances itself among the small twigs. Interesting papers about this bird appeared in Vols. II. and IV. of our Magazine, the latter containing an account of its nesting in captivity. In the town I saw a small green Ring- )\0x25A0 necked Parrakeet in a cage, and on the balcony of a private house was a large cage with about twenty small foreign birds in it In the afternoon of the next day I climbed up Mount Gouraia, which lies to the back of the town ; from the top were obtained magnificent views of the Gulf in front, while range upon range of mountain-chains stretched inland as far as the eye could reach ; the slopes are covered with a thick mass of scrub, and a plantation of Aleppo Pines grows about two-thirds of the way up. Many birds were about but were very shy ; I saw and heard Blackbirds and Ravens, and on the way down I saw a fine P'alcon flying along the face of some precipitous cliff--it looked like a Peregrine--and just as dusk was coming on three Barbary Partridges flew across the road just in front. Some Lapwings vyere also seen near the town.

Verv few Spar- es were seen at Bougie, which we left before eleven o'clock in e 11101 ning, tiavelling all day through fertile plains with fine 11s more 01 less neai ; at one place the ground was covered ith a thick growth of low scrub Palms. We arrive at Algiers :ortly after seven o'clock. Next day the Museum at Mustavo Superieur was visited ; contains a dilapidated collection of dusty stuffed birds and animals, apparently nothing of much interest and onlv few in lmbei. I11 the gardens of the Governor's summer palace was 'small round enclosure which contained some Barbary Doves, so one Turtle Dove and a hybrid Turtle x Barbary. On the T following the beautiful Botanical Gardens, known as the rdin d'Essai, were visited ; there is a poor little Zoo there with ly a very few birds, but I noticed a nice Desert Buzzard. The strich enclosure was covered with a mass of beautiful purple d scarlet Bougainvilleas. O11 the morning of the 9th I again visted the Jardin Sssai, but only saw Sparrows, Blackbirds, Pipits and some arblers which seemed to belong to the genus Phylloscopus ; and 11st caught sight of a very small bird, possibly a Wren. Dur- ? the night there was a sharp thunder-storm accompanied by il. December 10th was devoted to an excursion to the Gorges la Clififa ; you go by train to Blidah, where a fine stud of Arab d Barb horses may be seen, and drive about ten miles, passing ough extensive Orange groves and vineyards, to the entrance the Gorges; just before arriving there we stopped to see a all cave. On the other side of the road were some steep rocks tli ivy and other greenery growing over them, among which re fully a dozen Barbary Apes (Alacacus hums') ; they were not all shy, and were only a few feet above our heads. They dis- rbed stones and sticks which almost fell 011 our heads below ; /eral were of considerable size, and some had small young nging to them; they kept uttering a sort of grunting note, the garden of the Inn at the head of the Gorge were a pair of rbary Partridges, the cock being in very good plumage ; below

them was a small Ape. We walked some distance down the Gorge ; its sides are very steep and high, and at one place where water was trickling down, the whole face of the cliff was covered with a beautiful veil of Maiden-hair ferns, while a pretty little yellow Narcissus was growing among the rocks. At one place more Apes were seen; there were only some few small bird? about, among these some Tits. On the opposite side of the valley, in a shallow depression in the rocks, a large flock of Rock- doves were sunning themselves and sheltering from the very cold and keen wind which was blowing. I watched them for some time; every now and then a bird would fly from one point to another so that their backs became plainly exposed to view; they were a good way up the cliff, so I may after all be mistaken, but I am of decided opinion that none of these birds had white rumps; there could be no question of the birds having been contaminated by tame birds in this remote spot, so that this appeared to be a genuine flock of Columba livia s chimp eri, which however only differs from the typical Rock-dove by being a little lighter in shade and by having the rump light grey like the back. Numerous instances are on record of blue-rumped Rock-doveshaving been obtained in Tunisia and Algeria; Mr. J. H. Gurney, jun., observed and procured specimens in Algeria in 1870, and Mr. Whitaker has examples from Tunisia and Morocco; but generally these have been obtained from among flocks of typically-coloured birds and have been supposed to have been the result of crosses with domestic birds. There must have been at least a hundred birds in the flock I saw. Suddenly the form of a great bird appeared over the top of the cliffs; it was a magnificent Bearded Vulture (Gypaetus barbatus) easily recognisable from its large size and long wedge-shaped tail ; it sailed rapidly across the valley on motionless wings, going at a great rate without seeming to make the slightest effort; it passed and repassed overhead several times, a wonderful sight, worth going many miles to see. While walking up one of the steep narrow streets of Algiers, which led up to the Chasbah, next da\% I came across a pair of Barbary Partridges in a cage hanging up over a vegetable shop; the proprietor showed me the birds, which were very

Notes o?i the Rock Bushfowl. me, he let the hen bird out of the cage; I agreed to buy them id brought them back with me. The Barbary Partridge is ry closely allied to the familiar Red-legged bird, differing from by having the crown of the head chestnut-red, the cheeks and roat bluish-grey instead of white, and the collar round the ck chestnut-red not black ; they are very handsome birds, and ese were so tame that I got quite fond of them. They were id to have been caught young, and I expect they had lived the small cage I saw them in ever since. We left Algiers at mid-day on the 12th on our return voyage Marseilles. A number of Gulls were flying about the neigh- urliood of the harbour; I recognised many Lesser Black- cked, mostly adults, but some large dark grey young birds obably belonged to this species; also several Yellow-levered irring.Gulls, and Black-headed Gulls were well represented; arge flock which seemed to be entirely composed of this last ecies followed the boat. Some Whales were seen sporting >se to the ship. We had a very calm passage ; next morning p Yellow-legged Herring Gulls were in sight. We arrived tside Marseilles early in the afternoon ; here a great many ack-headed and a few Yellow-legged Herring Gulls were ing about. The journey across France was accomplished in a leisurely
algorithms.listItem: hion by stopping at Arles, Avignon and Paris. We landed ely in England on December 15th, having spent five weeks 1 of interest and enjoyment, to which the birds contributed 110 small degree.
algorithms.bodyText: P/ilopachys fuscus. By Dr. E. Hopkinson. I was much interested to see in the April number of the igazine that Mr. H. D. Astlev was the fortunate possessor of a ir of " Rock Bushfowl " (Ptilopachys fiiscus ). These birds are not at all common in the Gambia, and it iy interest him and perhaps other members to hear a little out the wild life of these charming little Game-birds, whose
Notes on the Rock Bushfowl.

resemblance to a dark-coloured Bantam is really quite extra- ordinary. Their general colour is chocolate brown, more rufous on the under surface of the wings; the bill and feet are pink, and they have a small comb of the same colour. The cock is a distinctly darker bird than the hen. They frequent the ironstone ridges which intersect a large part of the more inland parts of the country, and which are covered with bamboo growth varied here and there with patches of thin scrub. Here they are found in pairs or small parties of about half a dozen, which lie very closely, and prefer to trust to their powers of hiding rather than their wings, as they will wait till almost trodden on before moving, and then they either scuttle away, exactly like frightened chickens, dodging in and out the rocks, or rise with a scuffle and scattering of dust to fly rapidly away for a few yards and then drop again into shelter. They never appear to perch 011 trees or to move far away from their customary haunts, and they must also be able to get along with very little water, at any rate during the dry season, for then there is never any on the hills they frequent, and one never sees them like other Game-birds going to or from water. Their note is a low-pitched whistle. They are not at all easy birds to shoot, as they are only flushed with difficulty, and even then are usually out of sight again in a second. If one is wounded it will generally be lost, as it will probably manage to struggle away into some hole in the rocks. In such holes, which are often very deep, they nest, commencing to lay about the end of May. The young after leaving the nest remain with their parents for some time. Their food must be found chiefly, if not entirely, 011 the ironstone hills, as one never sees them on the cultivated ground. It probably consists mainly of the seeds of bamboos and various grasses with a considerable addition of insect-life as well. I had one in captivity for some time ; it ate any of the common native corns and was also very fond of boiled rice, while white ants, when obtainable, were always greedily devoured. Although so common here, I have never heard of one being caught by the natives, who catch a good many of our Common Bush-fowls (Francolins) in primitive traps or horse- hair nooses.
algorithms.title: Notes on Birds of Paradise. 277
algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON BIRDS OF PARADISE. By Walter Goodfellow.
algorithms.bodyText: INTRODUCTION. The following notes on some of the Birds of Paradise are :hiefly from observations made during various visits to New Guinea and some of the adjacent islands for the purpose of >rocuring living specimens of these remarkable and beautiful >irds, and date back from my first visit in 1903 up to the present ear. Unfortunately I am writing these notes entirely from nemory, not having brought my note-books out with me to sTew Guinea; hence they will not be so comprehensive as they night otherwise have been. Likewise I much regret having 110 vorks of reference with me. for I constantly read remarks about hese birds which are altogether wrong, and some purely im- ginative and needing correcting. Except perhaps in the British art of New Guinea few white men have had an opportunity of feeing the rarer species in their native haunts, as these all inhabit tie mountains which, apart from their steepness, are the most laccessible in the whole world, and only to be approached trough swamps and tangled jungle, the abode of fever and ostile natives, not to speak of insect plagues and other dis- omforts. Unlike the feathered inhabitants of these parts, the uman animal is of the lowest, and travelling alone, as I have itherto done, I have found it requires all one's resolution rouglit to bear to keep from succumbing to the gloom and meliness of it all. After landing my consignments in England I have had ut little opportunity to study them after they have settled down > aviary-life, when so much might be found out about them, specially about their various modes of display, but often the little have observed has quite upset theories I had formed during ie time some of the species where in my charge. Doubtless, in me, Mr. Brook, of Hoddam Castle, will be able to give us all >rts of interesting information about Paradise Birds under these mditions, for he has the finest living collection ever brought to- other, comprising 110 less than nineteen species, some of them the ost beautiful of the whole family. The cult of the Paradise-

Bird may be said to have commenced in 1904, when I brought over a small consignment for Mrs. Johnstone, consisting of one Greater Bird, two Lesser Birds, two Kings, and a pair of Black Manucodes. I always feel that aviculturists are much indebted to Mr. and Mrs. Johnstone, whose liberality in providing the means to fit out expeditions has enabled them to see these birds established as inmates of the aviaries at home, also on the show benches, while numbers have been on exhibition at the Zoo. Later, Sir William Ingram and Mr. Brook have both sent out expeditions for the same purpose, and been the means of introducing still further species to this country. These importations have con- clusively proved one thing, that Paradise Birds are by no means so delicate as they were atone time supposed to be; in fact, I think it may safely be said that generally they are hardy birds. So far none have bred in captivity, but I see no reason why they should not do so, and I feel sure, now that the treatment of them is better understood, that before long we shall hear of success in this direction. It is only about three years ago that the first females of any species were imported. These notes will be confined to those I have imported alive, which, with the Gardener Bower Birds, consists of twenty species, namely : The Greater (. Paradisea apoda), the Lesser (P. minor), the Red ( P . rubra). Count Raggi's (P. raggaina), the Twelve-wired (Seleucides ?iigrica?is ), the Port Moresby Rifle-Bird ( Ptilorhis biterccdens), the King ( Cicinnurus regius), Hunstein's Magnificent (.Diphyllodes hunsteini ), the Lesser Superb ( Lophorhina minor), Lawes' Six-plumed (. Parotia lawsei), D'Alberti's Southern (. Dre - pa?iornis cervinicauda), Meyer's Sickle-Bill ( Epimachus meyeri), the Princess Stephanie's (Astra?chia stephanice). Prince Rudolph's ( Paradisomis rudolphi), the Black Manucode ( Manucodia aira), the Purple-violet Manucode (flZ. purpureo-violacea ), the Green Manucode (M. viridis). Lady McGregor's ( Loria maria), and two specimens of Gardener Bower Birds (. Amblyomis subala?'ts and A. inornata). * * * * The Greater Bird of Paradise (Paradisea apoda). The Aru Islands off the S.W. coast of New Guinea are usually considered the chief home of this species, but it also inhabits the mainland in the interior south of the Charles Louis

Notes on Birds of Paradise. 279 and the Snow Mountains, which form the dividing line N. and S. between the Greater and Lesser Birds. We have recently met with it on the upper Mannika River, but it was not until we had gone nearly 40 miles inland that we first heard their cry, and so far they appear not to be at all common. The natives had often brought the plumes to trade at the base camp, and I took them to belong to the Lesser Bird, because being always old and dirty it was impossible to recognise them. When I first heard their -all up the liver it struck me as sounding too vigorous for P. minor , and I remarked it to one of our party at the time ; then ater on, when specimens were brought in, I saw they were apodas , but certainly smaller than those from the Arus. The Dutch have ately been exploring several of the rivers down this coast, and I lave heard that in each case no Paradise Birds were met with intil they had got some considerable distance inland. I11 the Aril Islands it is by 110 means distributed equally M over the group, but confined to the deepest jungle of the xtreme interior where the trees are tallest, and it requires a tood gun to reach them at all. I first went to the Arus in December 1903. This was *efore the advent of the pearl fishers from Thursday Island, and was at that time the only Kuropean in the country. I made *ilbattabatta my headquarters. It was then a flourishing village ir along the north bank of the Wanumbai channel. These urious channels intersect the Islands from one side to the other nd wind about in every direction. Some are navigable for hallow draught boats, and through others only the smallest anoes can pass. As the islands are very flat, the banks of most f them present an unbroken line of mangoose swamp, but 011 ae Wanumbai channel the jungle conies down to the water's dge, except round the villages where the ground is more or less leared. The Silbattabattas were at war with the Wanumbais of le south banks of the channel, so my search for birds had to be onfined solely to the forests on the north shore. I soon saw it 'as useless for anyone to come out here thinking they would be ble to catch or shoot apodas themselves, for the natives look pon the birds absolutely as their own property. This is hardly > be wondered at when the trade in skins has been carried 011

Mr. Walter Goodfellow, for generations; and, though this was one of the earliest species known, there is practically still everything to learn about them. Dr. Wallace, some fifty or more years ago, was the first to throw any real light on their habits. I had been established at Silbattabatta quite two weeks without seeing or even hearing the sound of an apoda , although I was out in the bush every day with native guides; and I was sure they purposely led me away from the district they frequented. At last I came to an understanding with them, and promised if they took me to their grounds I would give them a present for every one I shot. This they agreed to do, and the next morning I set out with six men, who took me, after about three hours walk, to a part of the forest which was different in appearance from any I had yet seen. The trees were taller, and the undergrowth not nearly so dense; and, instead of the usual coral rock, which seems to crop up everywhere in the Aru forests, the ground was covered with beautiful lycopodium moss, which made walking much easier. It was not long before I heard those loud ringing calls which I have since learnt to know so well, but it is im- possible to convey to anyone the thrill it sent through me at the time; the whole surroundings were mysterious, the green gloom of the jungle with its strange vegetation, my silent, wild-looking, dark-skinned companions, and then to be at last so near to the birds I had come so far to see. A little further, and there in the tops of the high trees were sixty or seventy restlessly flying from branch to branch, picking a fruit here and there and apparently not at all afraid, although they could plainly see us below. I found at this season the males were all out of plumage, but I noticed several had the yellow heads, but the majority of them appeared to be females or young males. Feeding in the same trees were several Black Manucodes, a couple of which I shot, a fine Cat-bird, and, on my way back, my first King Bird. I learnt from the natives that the dancing-trees, which are used by the birds only when they are in plumage, were still some distance further on. Every tribe claims the trees in their district, and should a man from another tribe trespass on the preserves of the other it means war, unless they are sufficiently friendly through intermarriage for the matter to be settled by the chiefs. In such

Notes on Birds of Paradise. a case a fine is usually demanded in the form of bronze trade gongs, obtained through the Chinese traders in Dobo. The dispute with the Wanumbais had originated in this way, and, when I arrived in the district, fighting had been going on in- termittently for two seasons. Peace was concluded before I left, as an even number had been killed on both sides. The Silbatta- battas kept the heads they had captured suspended from a tree in the middle of the village, just facing my house, and it was somewhat weird to hear them speak of each head by name, giving details of family history and the manner in which he was killed. I may add that these particulars were not always creditable to the captors, and in almost every case showed the grossest treachery. In 1904 apoda skins were fetching forty shillings each in Dobo (the one trading station of the islands) and this price appears to have increased last year to fifty and fifty-five shillings, owing to a great decrease in the numbers. About four years ago Customs were established in Dobo, and a ten per cent, export duty levied on the skins. The collector of Customs kindly gave me the returns for the first year, which amounted roughly to 1,100 skins of apodas. These figures would include only those sent away in bulk. There would certainly be more taken out in personal baggage and not declared. A European firm in Makassar, now takes, by contract with the Chinese, the whole of the skins obtained during the season. Their numbers must have considerably diminished during the last few' years, as when I passed through Makassar last June, I was told that about 650 only were collected the previous season, and this is not because the birds are less hunted than formerly; 011 the contrary, they were never so persecuted as they are now. The apodas resort to the same dancing trees year after year, and at the commencement of the season (March) the owners of the trees are able, before the birds' plumes are quite mature, to estimate almost to a skin the number they will obtain when shooting commences. A chief once told me that the preceding year he was only one bird out in his calculations, more or less, I quite forget now. This really means that each year possibly not one full-plumaged bird escapes. Formerly they were all shot

with blunt arrows, but now in some districts the natives art supplied with guns by the traders, and some possess guns o their own. When arrows are used the hunter is concealed unde: a shelter of boughs placed over a small platform in an adjoining tree. I have never been in the Aril Islands during the actua shooting season, but I have seen many of these platforms re maining in situ , and others in course of construction for the approaching time, and in no case were they ever in the dancing trees themselves. The heads of the arrows are of several shapes some are flat and round on the top, much the same as a lotus when gone to seed, but not so large ; others are merely a knot of wood, but the more usual shape has three blunt projecting spurs, cut from the natural fork of a branch. The display is called " Sakaleli," which is the word used generally for the native war-dances. The shooter takes up his position in the tree at daybreak, as the birds assemble at seven a.m. and again in the late afternoon, but the morning dance is the most important. Il the Greater Bird is anything like the Lesser he is in such a state of excitement at these times that he would not be disturbed .much even by the report of a gun, but I shall have more to say about this when writing of the Lesser Bird. The males are in full plumage by the end of April, and remain so until November, when they commence to moult. In England they appear to reverse the seasons, which is a pity, as comparatively few people see them at the Zoological Gardens when they are at their best during the winter. In captivity they lose the rich golden yellow on the head, which becomes a very pale straw colour, as it does also in skins. Strange to say, a full-plumaged male, which I brought home last year, had a broad band of white round the nape, becoming narrower at the sides as it reached the green of the throat. When last I saw it the white colour was very con- spicuous, but probably after it has moulted out, and the yellow head become paler, it will scarcely be noticeable at all. This bird is in the Hoddam Castle aviaries, and is otherwise perfectly normal. Apodas quickly become tame in captivity, especially in a cage. The old male, which lived for so long at the Zoo, became quite tame within three weeks after he was caught, and displayed every day as far as his limited cage-room allowed, even
algorithms.title: Notes on Birds of Paradise .
algorithms.bodyText: n board a ship in the Indian Ocean during the S -W. monsoon, dien the boat rolled so much that it was impossible to keep ;ater in the tins unless very deep. In their native forests they re not accustomed to take any long flights, neither is there any eed for them to do so, when all the trees are in one inextricable angle. They have the same zigzag way of ascending trees in onimon with all the Paradise Birds. The nesting season appears to commence in December, ast as the males have gone out of plumage, for I had an egg rought to me early in that month, during my last visit to the slands, and a few days later the same native took another to Sir Villiam Ingram's collector, who was staying in the same district, 'he man said he got them both from the same nest, but there was remarkable difference in the colouring of the two. While Mr. 'ratt's was almost white, with comparatively few markings, mine fas very pink and richly streaked all over, but more especially t the base. At the same time, together or apart, there could be o question as to their being the eggs of a Paradise Bird. The ative who brought them being a particularly stupid person, not peaking much Malay, I could get no satisfactory information *0111 him about the nest, whether it was high up or low down. 11 all probability it was low down like the raggiana's, and that .vo eggs is the usual number, with a possible three at times, hiring the first week in January Mr. Pratt had a young apoda rought to him alive, which a native had caught in the jungle, t must have fallen from the nest, as it was able to fly but little, 'he wings seemed to be developed out of proportion to the rest f the body, with the exception of the legs and feet, which, even t this age, were almost the normal size of those of an adult bird. Lidging from the young raggianas I reared from the nest two ears ago, this is the usual development, and in my notes on that pecies I shall have more to say about it. The young apoda , ith the help of its strong feet and claws, climbed about the aim-leaf walls of the native house and even up 011 to the rafters. : was some weeks before it used its wings for flight, although ad it remained in the jungle it would have flown long ago, but 1 captivity, owing to adverse circumstances, its development as retarded. The thighs remained perfectly bare of feathers

Mr. Walter Goodfellow, for quite two months after it was brought in, as also did tli throat and forehead. I noticed the same thing with th ragoia?ias, that the parts which are green in the adult male wer the last to acquire any feathers. The eyes were brownish viole at first, but gradually became browner after the first month which colour they apparently retain tor the first year. Judging from subsequent experience, I should say that this bird was quit three weeks old when it was caught, and had it remained in tin bush it would have fed itself in a few more days, but in captivit' it made no attempt to do so until fully a month later. Whethe it eventually lived to get to England I never heard. I thinl there can be no doubt that almost, if not all, the family an polygamous, and certainly those of this genus are. The Aru natives have various ways of catching Paradise Birds, and probably now, along the Wanumbai channel at am rate, they are more expert at it than ever they were, as severa collectors have been out there within the last few years Formerly the few apodas kept in captivity had been stunned b\ the hunters' blunt arrows, and were often more or less injured,r broken wing being the usual injury. Now they catch them bj means of snares placed in the feeding-trees, or better still, in the dancing-places. Bird-lime, prepared from the sap of the guttr percha tree, is also much used, but makes the birds in a fearfulh sticky condition. Unlike some of the other members of the family, there is no difficulty about getting newly-caught apodas tc feed. Being greedy birds they take readily to almost any kind of fruit, and even to the mixture used at home for insectivorous birds. Unless they are freely supplied at first with live insects or some animal food I have found them liable to fall off in con- dition and die. I have found the yolk of hard-boiled egg the best preventative for this, and when once they have taken to it I had no further fear for them. It is a difficult matter to get a thin bird back to condition. For one apoda I allowed the yolk of one e &g P er day. I have found it quite impossible to keep two males of this species together, at any rate in a cage, and I always thought it would be impossible in an aviary also, but recently in Amboina I saw three adult males together in a not very large aviary, but they were mixed up with parrots, pigeons, and other
algorithms.title: Notes on Birds of Paradise.
algorithms.bodyText: rds, which probably was the reason they did not fight. When ice they start to fight they usually both get killed, as with eir powerful claws they grip each other's throats and peck the es out, and even when taken in the hands it is all but im- >ssible to separate them. It is also risky to place even a true iir together in a cage, for, undoubtedly at certain seasons of e year the sexes separate, and as likely as not the female will tack the male, and perhaps injure him fatally, or else worry m so that he does not get sufficient to eat, and dies. Although in their native islands they are accustomed to e same tropical temperature nearly all the year round, they em to be able to stand a good deal of cold in England, and en on the voyage over I have found them far less susceptible cold and variations in the temperature than some of the ountain species naturally used to a certain amount of cold. The last time I was collecting in the Artis I took down ith me a couple of male Red Birds of Paradise from Waigiou. t Dodo I hired a large prau, on which I lived for ten days, :ploring some of the intricate channels I have already spoken , on the look out for a good collecting ground. The rubras ges were placed on deck, and often in the early mornings the >odas on shore replied to their calls, and even once or twice owed themselves in the trees at the water's edge. As I have remarked before, the males commence to assem- e irregularly in the dancing-trees even before the moulting ason is completely over. Occasionally it happens that a recog- sed dancing-tree is tabooed by the birds for a whole season, or ;rhaps longer ; indeed I heard of one tree which was deserted r three whole seasons, although the old chief of the district id never before remembered a season when it had not been ied. Of course this was put down to the fault of the shooters' tio had failed to duly propitiate the spirits, or had not given em the first offerings, which usually consist of the legs of the st bird shot that year. These are fastened to the trunk of the ee, together with a small bunch of plumes; in fact, a bird is ldom shot without a few of the plumes being pulled out and ruck into the tree somewhere. A traveller, unacquainted with 1 e custom and coming upon a dancing-tree in the jungle, would

Notes on Birds of Paradise . be puzzled to understand the meaning of the miscellaneoi offerings piled around. These consists of bronze trade gong china plates and bowls, empty cartridge cases, mysterious packe tied up in leaves, half cocoanut-shelis containing offerings tobacco, betel nut, &c., also with copper coins, and sometim even silver. A recognised ritual of incantation is made win the offerings are placed there and great privacy preserved, as would not do for another person to see it. W itliout my notes I have quite forgotten the native At name for the apoda , but the usual Malay trade name of " buron mate ' dead birds, is understood everywhere. The name orig nated through the early Malay traders knowing them only froi the dead skins. In travelling through the Archipelago on m way back to Singapore, it often sounded strange, when stoppin at some island, to hear one Malay call to another " to come an see the live dead birds." On our first journey of exploration recently up the Minik River, I was much impressed one day by a comparison betwee man, as he is in those parts, and the so-called lower animals, a represented by this beautiful highly-developed species of Paradis Bird. After travelling for five days up the river, we had tha evening come in touch with the first of the upper river tribee The following morning, as we approached a mud bank, we fount some wild-looking, naked men, waiting for us, who, on th approach of our canoes, threw themselves on the ground ant rolled and wallowed in black slimy mud and plastered it ove their heads and faces so that every part of their bodies wa covered with it. More degraded objects it would be impossiblt to conceive, yet while all this repulsive exhibition was going 01 some Greater Birds of Paradise were feeding and calling in tilt trees just over their heads. The contrast between the two coulc not have failed to strike most people. We have found two names on the Minika for the apoda- " tamuku " and "yau." (To be cojitijiuedJ.
Stray Notes on Indian Birds.

By Frank Finn, B.A., F.Z.S. (Continued from Page 191.) Greenshank. Totanus glottis. Blanford, quoting Oates, gives the bill of the Greenshank lark olive-brown, darker at the tip ; I have found it French- y, with the tip black. Ruff and REEVE. Pavoncella fugnax. Blanford gives the legs and feet of these birds as fleshy ow to yellowish-brown in adults; I have usually found them gilt orange, and the bill is often orange at the base. Many cimens in the Calcutta Bazaar had portions of the toes miss- 1, the stumps being quite healed over, and deformed claws e also common. It would be interesting to know what causes ects so extremely rare, otherwise, among wild birds, and ecially why they should occur in this very hardy species. Red-necked Phalarope. Phalaropiis hyperboreiis. Between Aden and Bombay, in 1907, I saw many flocks of ilaropes, which were very wild, and rose at a distance from ship. Painted Snipe. Rostratula capensis. A young bird of this species which I obtained before it : fledged, and reared, feeding it upon maggots and canary- 1 given in water, "swore" and showed off its wings like an It. I have seen one of these birds drive off the Eastern den Plover ( Cha?ad?ins Julvus), a bird pugnacious enough to r e a Ruff, by this wing-displav. Gull-billed Tekn. Sterna anglica. This bird would be better called the Gull-legged Tern, for most noticeable difference from other Terns is in the longer and consequently easy walk, unlike the waddle of Terns ierally. One I got for the Calcutta Zoo devoured maggots -dilv. Terns were constantlv sold in the Calcutta market in j j time as Plovers, when the fraud could be worked, and a fine lection could easily be obtained by any aviculturist finding self there in winter.

Shay Notes o?i Indian Birds. Sooty Tern. Ster?ia fuliginosa. As Terns are supposed to swim but little, I may menti that I have seen three of this species swimming together in t Red Sea. Indian Skimmer. Rhynchops albicollis. I have had specimens of this curious bird and found th would take shrimps and fish from the hand, though owing to t " under-shot" formation ol the bill they could not pick them 1 from the ground. White or Roseate Pelican. Pelecanus onocrotalus. The Calcutta Zoo obtained a full-plumaged pair in my til from Europe, and these, to my great astonishment, changed ba into immature plumage and then back again to full colour. Little Cormorant. Phalacrocorax javanicus. This bird is supposed to have a young plumage much li that of the young of our Common Cormorant ( P . carbo ), and certainly saw some of these brown white-breasted birds amor the fledged young of the wild colony of the species in t Calcutta Zoo ; but the colouration of most of the young I saw Calcutta was black like that of the parents, though some I rear* and sent to the Calcutta Zoo, where they were kept confine assumed the supposed immature plumage later on. The nestin down is black, but there is none on the forehead, and the bare sk there is white like human skin, giving a very comical effect. Tli species walks, either in a semi-erect or horizontal position, we enough, and is active on trees; I have seen a young bird turn i head back to sleep, with the wings still spread out, after it In been in this well-known Cormorant pose. My captive birds pr duced no castings, like the Shag (Z 3 . graculus ), and unlike tl Common Cormorant. Indian Darter or Snake Bird. ( Plotus melanogaster'). In this bird the down of the young is white. I have see a captive one asleep with the wings still expanded, so, takin this evidence with that of the last species, I think Newton w< wrong in doubting the fishermen's statement that our Cormorai may sleep in this position. ( To be continued .)

Sir,--A t the annual spring sale of the Antwerp Zoological Garden, bought a pair of Emblema picta, which I kept for some time in a large gilt cage of my bird house. As the weather got warmer, now some three weeks ago, I put the :tle birds in a warm sheltered out-door aviary. The birds seemed to like the change very much ; their plumage and aieral condition improved, and the male began to sing a good deal. This tie song is very simple and not much of a song in any way, but he seems take great pains about it, and looks very proud when he is at it. The birds after a while began to collect nesting material in a square \0x25A0x, and built a large, dome-shaped nest, using the material of two iinmon Wrens' nests and one Robins'. As the birds are since a few days only visible in turns, I presume that ey have eggs, and are incubating. Emblema picta are very quiet little birds, which in many of their tie ways remind me of the Red-shouldered Finch from Africa ( Pytelia cenicoptera). Rather striking is the pearl-white iris of these birds which gives them sharp expression. Gooilust , 27th May. - F. E. Bi.aauw. THE PIN-TAILED WHYDAH. Sir,--I have to thank Mr. Teschemaker for his courtesy in obtaining much information as he was able to secure respecting the breeding of is species in captivity. Unfortunately it leaves the question of the rasitic nature of the bird just where it was. Haagner is mistaken if he asserts that Roberts mentioned any other ds than Waxbills as hosts to Vidua principalis : he specifies Estrilda 'rilda and Estrilda dufresnii, and recommends African oologists to amine with greater care all nests of Waxbills which they may come ross.* Mr. Teschemaker asks why I do not settle the question once for all breeding the species. He says I have leisure, suitable aviaries and perience. In reply I may say that my experience has not helped me ich in breeding species, for the simple reason that my aviaries are not d never were suitable for breeding most birds--certainly not for Whydahs, ice they contain no growing grasses. I have also abolished one of my t-door aviaries, because it only produced me one young bird in two Hrs ; whereas, as a plant-house, it will be most useful. Excepting in the winter months I have very little leisure, or have t had hitherto, for I have been constantly occupied in the " making of y the way I wrongly quoted the article as 2nd Ser., Vol. I; it should be xst Ser. Vol. III.

many books," in answering numerous correspondents, in attending to tl wants of my insectivorous birds, and in keeping my conservatory ar garden in order. Now that I have practically completed the secor volume of my "Foreign Birds for Cage and Aviary" I shall perhaps ha' a little more leisure, and shall need it for work in my new plant-house. - A. G. Butler. MR. FROST'S CORRECTION. The return of Mr. Frost from Demerara with the collection he h. there made for Sir William Ingram, is of course the great avicultural evei of the month. The birds are now on deposit at the Zoological Gardens, ai the six Cocks of the Rock (Rupicola crocea) four adult and two immatu males, are attracting great attention. This species, however, has bee represented at the Gardens before, and the really greatest novelty of tl collection is a little Manakin, apparently the female of the Blue-backe species (Chiroxiphia pareola), the first of this South-American group fruit-eating birds to be imported. In appearance it is not unlike the he VioletTanager, but larger; the male would be black, with a turquoise-bh back and scarlet crest expanding transversely when erected.

algorithms.bodyText: Third Series VOL. I. -- No. 10 .--All rights reserved. AUGUST 1910 A PET CASSOWARY. Ccisuarius picticoliis. By E. J. Brook. Visitors to the Zoological Gardens can see the subject of hese remarks in the Cassowary house. The bird is the Painted- lecked Cassowary, and was caught by Mr. Goodfellow in Papua ibout fifteen months ago, being then a small chick of about a ortnight old. The bird accompanied the expedition during the whole of ts wanderings. At 10,000 feet "Kitty," as the bird was named, elt the cold a good deal, and I believe passed many a night ucked up in Mr. Goodfellow's bed. When " Kitty " first reached ny aviaries she was a delightful pet, would follow anywhere like dog, and loved to race and play with children. During all last autumn and most of the winter the Casso- wary passed wandering practically where she liked, doing little amage, except in the rock garden, which she stripped of every iempervivum she could reach, the round balls of the plants eing swallowed like pills. As the bird grew she got rather too udependent, hiding herself when shutting up time came, and ccasionally straying long distances anti causing much astonish- lent at various farms she visited. On one of these journeys she wain the river Annan--this was in January--and the river was mining cold and big, but the cold water did her no harm, 'here is nothing "Kitty" hates more than a dog; on one occa- on she chanced to see a hound in the park that was on its way ) the kennels, having been left out the previous day, she caught lat hound and gave it the worst licking it ever had in its life.

Mr. W. E. Teschemaker, I was really sorry to part with " Kitty," but it was quite necessary to do so as she took to kicking and is enormously powerful. I noticed that this bird was particularly fond of a mud bath, she would wallow in any dirty ditch, and when dry the soil would shake out of her liair-like feathers, leaving her clean and glossy. For food she took household bread and potatoes chiefly, she was also fond of well-boiled rice, but a bowl of dry " B. C. " food was looked upon as a particular treat. Apples cut into irregular pieces, also cabbage leaves and bits of the stalks were much appreciated. Earth worms, small birds and mice were swallowed whole. "Kitty" was only ill once, and that for only a short time after eating a number of wire staples. Cassowaries should have a fairly long trough to drink out of;-they do not suck the water up, but take a long sweeping scoop with the beak wide open, and they find a great difficulty in scooping up enough water from a round vessel such as a bucket.

Serimis sulphur a tus. By W. E. Teschemaker, B.A. This Seedeater is one of the most charming songsters: brilliant in colour, the male being a deep golden yellow : abso- lutely hardy and perfectly peaceable. What better subject could one want for an aviary bird ? And yet it is hardly ever imported (though a common species in South and South-East Africa), and, even if it were imported more frequently, it would probably only fetch a few shillings. What a strange tiling it is to see our members tumbling over one another in their eagerness to acquire such useless birds as Parrot Finches and overlooking real merit! I11 six years I have only been able to pick up four in- dividuals--two males and two females--and one of the latter, purchased from a member, was of so venerable an age that it really did not count. (N.B.--I am always very pleased to get hold of acclimatised birds, but I wish some of our members would not "pass 011 " birds which really ought to be in receipt

on the Nesting of the Sulphury Seedeater. of old age pensions). Not only is this species rarely imported, but it does not seem to be as well known as it deserves to be For instance, in Dr. Butler's excellent " Foreign Finches in Cap- tivity" the female is described as "slightly duller than the cock, with less-defined yellow streak on the face." Both the females that I have seen have been dark grey with whitish throat and super- ciliary streak and dull reddish-yellow rump. The male can sing as well as a Cape Canary and both sexes have a curious call-note which sounds to me exactly like the words "Pleased to see you." I feel sure there can be no difficulty in breeding this species, and yet, out of fifteen nests and no less than sixtv e^s only two young were hatched. One of these, hatched in 1905, grew to be a good size but disappeared in the usual mysterious manner just before it was ready to leave the nest. Practically every clutch has consisted of four eggs, and of these three have usually been light bine with a few black spots on the larger end and the remaining egg unspotted. O11 the 8th July, 1909, I found one young one some days old in the nest: it was thinly covered on the head and back with whitish down. O11 the 13th it had quill feathers in the wings. O11 the 15th its eyes were open: its beak was yellowish and lighter in colour than the adults. On the 20th it left the nest and was then a light buff-grey with bold, dark brown striations 011 the breast and smaller ditto on the back; there was some yellow 011 the margins of the primaries, and it resembled its mother in its light superciliary stripe and pale yellow rump. It retained a little down on the head until the 25th. It was a fine youngster, and naturally its mother was immensely proud of it, being the only child of her old age, but, when she went to nest igain, I regret to say that its father used to neglect it and even drive it away from the food-tins. So on the 1st August I placed it by itself in the next division of the aviary, and here it seemed to get on well, but on the morning of the 7th [ picked it up dead out well nourished. It certainly did seem hard that the first young Sulphury I ever succeeded in rearing should have been so quickly snatched away by the grudging hand of Fate. I have always been careful to provide myself with actual proof of nesting results--I think one owes this to oneself as well

Mr. Frank Finn, as to the Society--so I sent the late lamented the same day to Sliopland, the taxidermist, of Torquay, to be made into a skin. The weather was sultry, and next day I got a post card from Shopland to say he could not make a skin of it. I wrote by return asking him to put it in spirits but when, by the following post, I received only a small handful of feathers I am afraid--to perpetrate a mild pun--that my remarks were also rather sul- phury. However, as I write (19 June, 1910), the old hen Sulphury --o-etting a little bald but otherwise wearing her years lightly-- is sitting again, and perhaps I may this season be able to produce something more tangible in the way of evidence. The old male is as gallant and debonair as ever: he sits by the nest and warbles to his better half and scoffs at Time. I have not been able to ascertain whether this species has been bred or not. P.S.--I see that Stark and Sclater say that " the young remain in the nest from three to four weeks." I wonder if this is correct. The young bird mentioned above left the nest about the 15th day and could feed itself by the 26th day.

By Frank Finn, B.A., F.Z.S. (Concluded from fage 288.) Masked Booby. Sula cyanops. I saw specimens between Aden and Bombay in 1898. Diving-Petrel. Peleca?ioides urinatrix. Blandford rejects the claim of this species to figure in the Indian list, but I saw, between Aden and Bombay, in the autumn of 1897, a short-winged black and white sea-bird which could hardly have been anything else. While on the subject of Petrels I may say that I have seen plenty, and never noticed that they ran along the water any more than Gulls do. White Stork. Ciconia alba. Storks are supposed to have no voice, but the young of this species certainly utter a wheezing squeak ; so do young American Jaberus ( Myderia americana).
Stray Notes on Indian Birds.

Painted Stork. Pseudo tantalus leucocephalus . I met a gentleman in India who told me that at a breed- ing-haunt of this bird he got the local natives to climb the trees and catch the old birds, then clipping off their pink wing-plumes and letting them go. This is a good harmless way of getting plumes, but birds would have to be very tame, even for India, to stand it! Cattle Egret. Bubulcus co?'o?na?idjis. This species eats cockroaches--the large Periplaneta ameri- cana --readily, as many as fifteen at a meal, and does not always cast pellets. But the specimen I observed cast a very perfect one after receiving some small birds broken up and, some time previously, cockroaches. The pellet contained some only of the bones, some feathers, and hard parts of the insects. Yet I saw no pellets after the Egret had received a Gecko lizard and several cockroaches, all at one meal. The gecko was given alive, and its tail came off on attack, as usual, but the bird did not let the reptile escape, but seized it again, and only ate the still-wriggling tail after the lizard was swallowed. Common Flamingo. Phoenicoptems roseus. These birds, not only swim well, but will turn "end up" to feed in deep water, like ducks ; at any rate, two I kept on the Museum pond did so. They also eat water-snails. With regard to the affinities of the Flamingo, I may remark that there are two points, independently of its anatomy, which ally it to the Stork and Ibis group rather than the Ducks ; one is that the young, although not helpless, are fed from the bill by the parents, and the other is that the young fledge like Storks, the wings being full-sized and well-quilled when there is still some down on the body, as may be seen in the just-fledged specimen of this species exhibited in the South Kensington Museum. I11 ducks, as everyone knows, the wings long remain small, and feather only when the bird is nearly full-grown and plumaged. Grey-lag Goose. Anset ferns. The common domestic goose of India has been supposed to be a hybrid between the domestic race of this bird and that of the Chinese Goose ( Cygnopsis eygnoides ), but I do not think this is right, as domestic Indian geese never, so far as I know,

Mr. Frank Finn, show any resemblance to the European tame geese ; they never, for instance, show any of the characteristic grooving of the neck- feathers conspicuous in the Grey-lag and its tame descendants and even in the hybrids of these with the Chinese goose. The gander of these Indian tame geese is quite as often pied as white, unlike what obtains in European common tame geese. Comb-Duck or Nukta. Scu-cidiornis melanonota. There is a good deal of variation in the speckled head- colour of the male in this species, some specimens having more black than white, while in others the white predominates. A male I got in immature plumage and sent to the Calcutta Zoo moulted out into a fine bird with a very light head, but, curiously enough, with the flanks nearly black, thus closely 7, resembling the American Comb-duck (S. carunculata). Whistling Teal. Dendrocygna javanica. The eyes of this bird are not only proportionately but absolutely larger than in its bigger Indian relative, the Large Whistling-teal or Fulvous Duck (D.fiilvci). These "Whistlers" dive as freely as Pochards, but with a spring like a Coot. The small species is very quarrelsome ; I have seen several unite on Rutledge's pond to attack Spotted-bills, and a Calcutta friend of mine, a very 7, observant sportsman, used to say r that whenever he heard that confounded whistling he know there would be no decent ducks on that tank--he despised Whistlers as not being fast enough on the wing for sporting shots ! Cotton Teal. Nettopus coroma?idelianus. I have (. Avicultural Magazine , VII., p. 131) described the courting gestures of the drake of this charming little species in our pages previously, but I may add here that the gesture of bending down the head is seen in both sexes when about to fight, and apropos of Cotton Teal's fights it is noteworthy that though females will attack males and each other as well, males will not fight females, though they will attack young drakes in the female- like immature plumage as well as their full-plumaged companions. Mandarin Duck. sEx galericulata. Although onlv once recorded in Indian limits as a wild o J bird (in Assam in 1902) this species is often imported alive from
Stray Notes on Indian Birds.

Ellina, and pinioning not being practised by natives, probably )ften escapes. I11 Calcutta in my time they cost 30 rupees (#2) I pair. I recently saw a female at the Zoo imitate her drake in he gesture of dipping the bill in the water, and then putting t behind the partly-opened wing, which looks so much like an ittempt to draw attention to his fan. Mallard. Anas boscas. The common domestic duck of India is descended from his species, and although the Muscovy (Cairina ?noschata') is nore often kept than here, it is, I think, chiefly known as a uiriosity. Hybrids between them are not uncommon, and have leither the curls of the Mallard's tail, nor the bare face of the )ther parent. The brown ones, which bear some resemblance o the Mallard in coloration (they are often black and white and iometimes grey and white), go into undress plumage like Mallard md common tame drakes. Some of these hybrids I kept were, niriously enough, more inclined to perch than the true Muscovy, oosting at night regularly in a tree. I have seen some stand vhen resting with the body erect like a Cormorant. The 'Indian runner" breed of tame duck, by the way, I never saw II India. Spotted-billed Duck. Anas pcecilorhyncha. Rutledge told me he had twice known a female of this pecies pair with a mallard-coloured tame drake. O11 the last *ccasion I saw the birds. Male Spotted-bills were also present nd ready to pair, and also two Mallards, but these were in- 'Lifferent. The late Mr. C. Fawns, formerly steward on one of he "City " line of steamers, who had much to do with waterfowl, old me that in Scotland the Spotted-bill when turned out crossed eadily with Mallard. The female in captivity is very apt to get he white webs of the tertiaries clouded with brown, not lone

iter the moult. I do not know how this colour conies in--per- taps by abrasion--but it is peculiar and significant that the >rown markings are of the same pattern as the dark markings 011 he corresponding feathers in the Mallard's female. Gadwall. Chanletasmns streperus. I once saw a male of this species in the Calcutta Bazaar iossed with plum-colour behind the eyes. The white wing-bar

Stray Notes o?i Indian Birds. is more conspicuous in the female in repose; but appears in the male when showing off; his courting gestures are like those o:| the Mallard, Pintail and Common Teal. Baikal Teal or Clucking Teal. (. Net Hum formosuni). I have before noted ( Avicultutal Magazine , N.S. V., p. 316'jj the variation in the colour of the feet, grey or olive, in this! species ; this has nothing to do with sexes as the following note"|l show. In 1901 there were a pair in the London Zoo, of which! the male had grey and the female olive feet; two males kept fori] sometime in the Calcutta Zoo both had olive feet. Of a consign-) ment which were brought to Calcutta from abroad in 1902, some had olive feet, but I did not note their sex ; and in a consignment! now with Mr. Hamlyn, I note some olive-footed ones. I have, however, only seen one specimen with the bill olive, an Indian-caught female, I procured in Calcutta market in the winter of 1898-99. In all others the bill has been grey, nor! have I noticed anv variation in the eves. Garganey. Querquedula circia. Of six specimens of the pallid or cinnamon variety of this duck I have seen, three were males and three females. Pochard. Nyroca ferina. Blau ford gives the irides of this duck as orange-yellow; I have usually found them red in the male,very rarely yellow; brown in the female, though I once saw a red-eyed female in St. James's Park. Eastern White-eyed Duck. Nyroca baeri. When this bird was obtainable during its invasion of India I placed some specimens on the Museum pond without pinioning them. Phils a full-winged male arrived some time during the winter of 1900-01 and stayed till May in the latter year, while a full-winged Common White-eye (yV. africana ) left long before. One full-winged bird even kept a pinioned pair company for more than a year, never flying, so far as I saw, till in his second 1 I caught him up during his moult and gave him away to go to England along with the pinioned birds. I ufted Duck. Nyroca fuligula. I his bird is supposed to be poor eating, but I have tried it in England, and found it tolerable enough. I11 this specimen's gizzard there was some coarse sand.

Notes 071 the Age of Birds in Confiiemeiit. 299 Golden-eye. Cla ? io 7 ila olaucion . My experience with eating this bird in England and finding land in its gizzard was similar to that with the last. I mention he sand because I have seen somewhere a statement that the living-ducks do not swallow this. Smew. Mergus albellus . A specimen they had in the London Zoo some years ago ite ordinary biscuits readily, even from the hand, and a Red- >reasted Marganser kept later would even eat bread. Goosander. A/eroa?tser meroaiiser. c> d Rutledge once had a consignment of these birds brought [own from the hills which had been fed solely on raw rice (not >addy, but husked as for cooking) ; I saw them eating it myself, nd they were in good condition. Taken in connection with what s said above, this shows that Mergansers can be fed to some xtent on vegetable food. Indian Dabchick. Podiccpes albipeiuiis. I have never observed any of the specimens of this bird I *ossessed eat their own feathers as other Grebes do.
algorithms.listItem: By J. Lewis Bonhote, M.A., F.L.S., F.Z.S. {Concluded from page 267). 7. Stork ( Ciconia albai). 9 years, still living; 5 years 11 months, 3 years 3 months.
algorithms.bodyText: Delightful tame and hardy birds in confinement. Mine were kept at liberty (pinioned) in the garden, with no artificial shelter. The living bird is this year sitting on eggs in the Zoological Gardens. They are practically omnivorous ; grain, bread and butter, young ducks, meat and fish--nothing comes amiss, but I would only recom- mend the latter.
algorithms.figure: 8. Spoonbill ( Platalea leucorodia). 3 years 1 month ; several died after two or three months.
algorithms.bodyText: 300 Mr. J. Lewis Bonhote, A very delicate species in captivity. Their food (fish) must be given them in water, cut up small, and the bones removed. They must be shut up in cold weather and would, I believe, do better with a moderate amount of heat, though mine never had that luxury. It eventually died of starvation, as it refused all food when moved from
algorithms.listItem: my Cambridge aviaries. 49. White-fronted Goose ( Anser albijrons). 7 years 3 months, still living, and 3 years 10 months. 50. Bean Goose (Anser segetuvi). 2 years 5 months. 51. Brent Goose ( Bemicla brenta). 8 years 1 month to 1 year 4 months ; four individuals.
algorithms.bodyText: Average 3 years 2 months. I have never kept many geese owing to lack of space, and with the exception of this species I have had to part with those I had. They seem to be very hardy and peaceful with other waterfowl.
algorithms.listItem: 52. Mandarin Duck (AEx gale?iculatd). 7 years 10 months and 4 years. 53. Summer Duck (AEx sponsa). 7 years 7 months. 54. White-faced Tree Duck ( De?idrocygna viduata). 2 years 5 months, still living, and 1 year 4 months. 55. SheelduCK ( Tador?ia cornutd). 7 years n months, still living. (These birds were just
algorithms.bodyText: fledged when I received them). 1 year 6 months. Five examples; average 5 years 4 months. Laid but did not incubate.
algorithms.figure: 56. Ruddy Shellduck ( Tadorna casarca). 5 years 7 months, still living and at present nesting in the Zoological Gardens. The Shellducks become delightfully tame in confinement, but drive other ducks about during the nesting season. 57. Wild Duck ( A?ias boscdas ). 10 years to 5 years 8 months ; four individuals. Average 7 years 9 months.
algorithms.bodyText: I kept very few of this species owing to the pugnacity of the males during the courting season. If the extent of

Notes on the Age of Birds in Confinement. water be limited it is almost impossible to breed ducks unless each pair be kept separate, but the breeding pen may be of extremely modest dimensions. This, of course, does not apply where one drake is kept with several ducks, but only when the sexes are approximately equal. In these cases each duck will be worried in turn by all the drakes, and, for a few weeks, will be given no peace or rest until eventually she is killed. Although this is a normal course in the case of Mammals, I have never known or heard of similar cases in birds. In ducks, how- ever, I have observed it every year. There is no doubt that ducks choose their own drakes, and in this species at least it seems more than likely that sexual selection plays a considerable part. In most cases birds once paired will, if opportunity occurs, mate again every year, although they may have been separated during the winter. The drakes remain with the duck until the young are hatched, after which they retire to moult. The assumption of the eclipse plumage of the drakes is, to a large extent, dependent on the hatching of the young, and although all drakes assume the eclipse plumage it usually shows itself much earlier in the year in breeding birds than on those which are not paired. Roughly speaking, under normal conditions, the eclipse plumage will first show itself about five weeks after the duck commences incubation. It is perhaps also worthy of note that, if suitable shelters are made, laying can be advanced by two or three weeks. In some of my pens bushy laurels were grown as nesting cover, whereas in others straw shelters were erected, and during the last four years, without exception, eggs were always laid in the straw shelters considerably before they were in the other pens. These notes refer largely to my hybrid ducks. (See also Avic. Mag., ist Ser., Vol. II., p. 160.)

algorithms.bodyText: A fairly hardy species, but does best if taken indoors during the winter. With this, as with all Waders, moult- ing is the main trouble; properly kept, most species will live until the autumn, but if they do not complete their moult before winter they are almost certain to die during February and March. Good food, combined with a little

Mr. J. Lewis Bonhote, artificial heat during August if the weather be cold, is the best means of bringing them through their moult. It should be borne in mind that most Waders pass the winter in the tropics and, in my opinion, the majority of adult birds reach their winter quarters during September, and do not leave them till April. Individuals met with in England after the middle of September are almost entirely birds of the year. In this species all the birds have left their breeding quarters by the middle of August. The spring moult is not so important, and many wild indi- viduals do not assume it completely.
